"metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1728826544.834038, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Here are step-by-step instructions on how to **test API interactions separately** to ensure that the external API, like OpenAI&#x27;s API, is functioning correctly and returning the expected response:\n\n### Step 1: Identify the API Call in Your Lambda Function\n- In your Lambda function code (or skill&#x27;s backend), look for the part where you are making the API call to the external service, like OpenAI. This will typically involve:\n  - An HTTP request to an API endpoint.\n  - Passing parameters such as the user\u2019s input or query.\n  - Receiving and handling the API&#x27;s response.\n\n### Step 2: Extract the API Request Code\n- Isolate the section of your Lambda function that makes the API call.\n- For example, in Node.js, it might look something like this:\n\n```javascript\nconst axios = require(&#x27;axios&#x27;);\n\nasync function callOpenAI(query) {\n    const response = await axios.post(&#x27;https://api.openai.com/v1/completions&#x27;, {\n        prompt: query,\n        max_tokens: 50,\n        temperature: 0.7\n    }, {\n        headers: {\n            &#x27;Authorization&#x27;: `Bearer YOUR_API_KEY`,\n            &#x27;Content-Type&#x27;: &#x27;application/json&#x27;\n        }\n    });\n    \n    return response.data;\n}\n```\n\n### Step 3: Test the API Call Locally\n#### Option 1: Use Postman\n1. **Download and Install Postman** (if not already installed): [https://www.postman.com/downloads/](https://www.postman.com/downloads/)\n   \n2. **Create a new HTTP request**:\n   - Set the method to `POST`.\n   - Enter the API endpoint (e.g., for OpenAI: `https://api.openai.com/v1/completions`).\n\n3. **Add Authorization Header**:\n   - Go to the &quot;Authorization&quot; tab or add the `Authorization` header manually.\n   - For OpenAI, you\u2019ll need to provide your Bearer Token, like so:\n     ```\n     Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY\n     ```\n\n4. **Set the Body**:\n   - Choose `raw` and `JSON` format for the body.\n   - Input a JSON payload that matches what your Lambda function is sending, for example:\n     ```json\n     {\n       &quot;prompt&quot;: &quot;the relationship between cops and donuts&quot;,\n       &quot;max_tokens&quot;: 50,\n       &quot;temperature&quot;: 0.7\n     }\n     ```\n\n5. **Send the Request**:\n   - Click the **Send** button.\n   - Postman will display the API response, including status code, response body, and any error details. If you receive a valid response, it means the API is working fine.\n\n#### Option 2: Use a Local Script\nIf you prefer to use code instead of Postman:\n\n1. **Create a new script** (in JavaScript, Python, etc.) to run locally.\n2. Copy the API call logic from your Lambda function into the script.\n3. Modify the query and ensure that the headers and body are correct.\n4. **Run the script locally** to check the API response.\n\nFor example, in Node.js:\n\n```javascript\nconst axios = require(&#x27;axios&#x27;);\n\nasync function testAPI() {\n    try {\n        const response = await axios.post(&#x27;https://api.openai.com/v1/completions&#x27;, {\n            prompt: &quot;the relationship between cops and donuts&quot;,\n            max_tokens: 50,\n            temperature: 0.7\n        }, {\n            headers: {\n                &#x27;Authorization&#x27;: `Bearer YOUR_API_KEY`,\n                &#x27;Content-Type&#x27;: &#x27;application/json&#x27;\n            }\n        });\n\n        console.log(response.data);\n    } catch (error) {\n        console.error(&quot;Error with API call:&quot;, error.response ? error.response.data : error.message);\n    }\n}\n\ntestAPI();\n```\n\nRun this script locally and check the console output for the API response.\n\n### Step 4: Debug the API Response\n- If the API responds successfully, check what is returned (e.g., the expected text completion for OpenAI).\n- If there is an error, the response should contain details such as:\n  - Invalid API key\n  - Malformed request body\n  - Too many requests (rate-limited)\n  \nThis information will help you debug the API integration in your Lambda function.\n\n### Step 5: Implement API Call in Lambda Function\n- After verifying the API works as expected, return to your Lambda function and ensure that:\n  - The API call is structured correctly.\n  - The data being sent to the API matches the required format.\n  - You handle errors appropriately (e.g., catch and log any errors during the API call).\n\n### Step 6: Monitor Logs in AWS CloudWatch\nAfter testing locally, you can re-deploy your Lambda function and then monitor the logs in **AWS CloudWatch** to ensure the API call is functioning correctly when triggered by your Alexa skill.\n\n#### How to View Logs in CloudWatch:\n1. Go to the **AWS Management Console** and open **CloudWatch**.\n2. Select **Logs** from the left-hand menu.\n3. Find the **log group** for your Lambda function (e.g., `/aws/lambda/YOUR_LAMBDA_FUNCTION_NAME`).\n4. Open the most recent log stream to view details of the function\u2019s execution.\n\nLook for errors related to API calls or unhandled exceptions in the log output.\n\n---\n\nThis process should help you verify if the API is working correctly, and once confirmed, you can adjust your Lambda code accordingly to handle any errors and integrate the API smoothly."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n  * Apache-2.0 license \n\n# Alexa Generative AI Skill \n\n[Image 0: Architectural Diagram]\n\n## About \n\nNode.js backend for an AWS Lambda function used by the &quot;Generative AI&quot; Alexa Skill. The function utilizes OpenAI&#x27;s Generative Artificial Intelligence API to generate responses in a natural conversation with the device.\n\nThe goal is to create an interactive and intelligent experience, allowing users to receive dynamic responses to a variety of questions and commands.\n\n## Architecture \ufe0f\n\nUsing the simple diagram above that illustrates the architecture\n\n  * Alexa Skill: Skill that receives voice commands from users.\n  * AWS Lambda: Lambda function that processes the received commands and interacts with the OpenAI API.\n  * OpenAI API: API that generates responses using generative AI based on the sent conversation.\n\n## Setup \n\n### Prerequisites\n\n  * AWS account with access to AWS Lambda and Alexa Skills Kit.\n  * OpenAI account with access to the OpenAI API.\n\n### Configuring the Alexa Skill\n\n  1. Create a new Alexa skill using the Alexa Skills Kit (ASK). Define the intentions and interaction models as needed.\n  2. Implement the skill logic that will process user inputs and interact with the Lambda function.\n\n### Configuring AWS Lambda\n\n  1. Upload the code from this repository to your Lambda function.\n  2. Set up Lambda trigger as Alexa/IoT and link your Skill ID.\n  3. Copy the Lambda function&#x27;s ARN and set it as the endpoint for your Alexa Skill.\n\n### Integration with OpenAI API\n\n  1. Obtain an API key from OpenAI.\n  2. Configure the OpenAI API credentials in the Lambda function code.\n\n## Testing and Deployment \n\n  * Test the skill using the Alexa test console or an actual Alexa device.\n\n## Limitations and Warnings \u26a0\ufe0f\n\n  * Developer Mode: This skill is only available in Developer mode, meaning it is not visible or accessible in the Skills Store and is only available for testing.\n  * Amazon Account: If you intend to test with a physical Alexa device (e.g., Amazon Echo, Echo Dot, Echo Show), the email of the Amazon account must be the same as that of the Alexa Skills Kit.\n  * Conversation History: The current version does not support conversation history.\n\n## About\n\nAlexa Skill integrated with OpenAI for dynamic AI-generated user interactions \n\n### Topics\n\n\u301065\u2020 nodejs \u3011 \u301066\u2020 alexa \u3011 \u301067\u2020 ai \u3011 \u301068\u2020 aws-lambda \u3011 \u301069\u2020 openai \u3011 \u301070\u2020 alexa-skill \u3011 \u301071\u2020 gpt-4 \u3011 \u301072\u2020 generative-ai \u3011 \n\n##", "title": "GitHub - PedroHaupenthal/alexa-generative-ai: Alexa Skill integrated with OpenAI for dynamic AI-generated user interactions", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "GitHub - PedroHaupenthal/alexa-generative-ai: Alexa Skill integrated with OpenAI for dynamic AI-generated user interactions", "url": "https://github.com/PedroHaupenthal/alexa-generative-ai", "text": "    * \u301017\u2020 Financial services \u3011\n    * \u301018\u2020 Manufacturing \u3011\n\nBy use case\n    * \u301019\u2020 CI/CD &amp; all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n  * Apache-2.0 license \n\n# Alexa Generative AI Skill \n\n[Image 0: Architectural Diagram]\n\n## About \n\nNode.js backend for an AWS Lambda function used by the &quot;Generative AI&quot; Alexa Skill. The function utilizes OpenAI&#x27;s Generative Artificial Intelligence API to generate responses in a natural conversation with the device.\n\nThe goal is to create an interactive and intelligent experience, allowing users to receive dynamic responses to a variety of questions and commands.\n\n## Architecture \ufe0f\n\nUsing the simple diagram above that illustrates the architecture\n\n  * Alexa Skill: Skill that receives voice commands from users.\n  * AWS Lambda: Lambda function that processes the received commands and interacts with the OpenAI API.\n  * OpenAI API: API that generates responses using generative AI based on the sent conversation.\n\n## Setup \n\n### Prerequisites\n\n  * AWS account with access to AWS Lambda and Alexa Skills Kit.\n  * OpenAI account with access to the OpenAI API.\n\n### Configuring the Alexa Skill\n\n  1. Create a new Alexa skill using the Alexa Skills Kit (ASK). Define the intentions and interaction models as needed.\n  2. Implement the skill logic that will process user inputs and interact with the Lambda function.\n\n### Configuring AWS Lambda\n\n  1. Upload the code from this repository to your Lambda function.\n  2. Set up Lambda trigger as Alexa/IoT and link your Skill ID.\n  3. Copy the Lambda function&#x27;s ARN and set it as the endpoint for your Alexa Skill.\n\n### Integration with OpenAI API\n\n  1. Obtain an API key from OpenAI.\n  2. Configure the OpenAI API credentials in the Lambda function code.\n\n## Testing and Deployment \n\n  * Test the skill using the Alexa test console or an actual Alexa device.\n\n## Limitations and Warnings \u26a0\ufe0f\n\n  * Developer Mode: This skill is only available in Developer mode, meaning it is not visible or accessible in the Skills Store and is only available for testing.\n  * Amazon Account: If you intend to test with a physical Alexa device (e.g., Amazon Echo, Echo Dot, Echo Show), the email of the Amazon account must be the same as that of the Alexa Skills Kit.\n  * Conversation History: The current version does not support conversation history.\n\n## About\n\nAlexa Skill integrated with OpenAI for dynamic AI-generated user interactions \n\n### \n\n\u301059\u2020.ask\u3011\n\n\u301059\u2020.ask\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020images\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020images\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020lambda\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020lambda\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020models\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020models\u3011\n\n\u301046\u2020LICENSE\u3011\n\n\u301046\u2020LICENSE\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020ask-resources.json\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020ask-resources.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020json_editor.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020json_editor.json\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020skill.json\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020skill.json\u3011\n\nView all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n  * MIT license \n\n# Alexa GPT\n\n[Image 0: License: MIT]\n\nBoost your Alexa by making it respond as ChatGPT.\n\nThis repository contains a tutorial on how to create a simple Alexa skill that uses the OpenAI API to generate responses from the ChatGPT model.\n\n[Image 1]\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n  * An \u301067\u2020Amazon Developer account\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011\n  * An \u301068\u2020OpenAI API key\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011\n\n## Step-by-step tutorial\n\n### 1. \n\nLog in to your Amazon Developer account and navigate to the \u301069\u2020Alexa Developer Console\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011.\n\n### 2.\n\nClick on &quot;Create Skill&quot; and name the skill &quot;Chat&quot;. Choose the primary locale according to your language.\n\n[Image 2: name your skill]\n\n### 3.\n\nChoose &quot;Other&quot; and &quot;Custom&quot; for the model.\n\n[Image 3: type of experience]\n\n[Image 4: choose a model]\n\n### 4.\n\nChoose &quot;Alexa-hosted (Python)&quot; for the backend resources.\n\n[Image 5: hosting services]\n\n### 5.\n\nYou now have two options:\n\n  * Click on &quot;Import Skill&quot;, paste the link of this repository (\u301070\u2020https://github.com/k4l1sh/alexa-gpt.git\u3011) and click on &quot;Import&quot;. [Image 6: template]\n\nOr if you want to create the skill manually\n\n  * Select &quot;Start from Scratch&quot; and click on &quot;Create Skill&quot;\n\n[Image 7: template]\n\n### 6.\n\nIn the &quot;Build&quot; section, navigate to the &quot;JSON Editor&quot; tab.\n\n### 7.\n\nIf you have directly imported the skill from this repository, just change the &quot;invocationName&quot; to &quot;chat&quot; or another preferred word for activation and proceed to step 12.\n\nHowever, if you chose to manually create the skill, replace the existing JSON content with the \u301065\u2020provided JSON content\u3011:\n\n    {\n        &quot;interactionModel&quot;: {\n            &quot;languageModel&quot;: {\n                &quot;invocationName&quot;: &quot;chat&quot;,\n                &quot;intents&quot;: [\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;slots&quot;: [\n                            {\n                                &quot;name&quot;: &quot;query&quot;,\n                                &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.Person&quot;\n                            }\n                        ],\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: [\n                            &quot;{query}&quot;\n                        ]\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.NavigateHomeIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    }\n                ],\n                &quot;types&quot;: []\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n[Image 8: json_editor]\n\n### 8.\n\nSave the model and click on &quot;Build Model&quot;.\n\n### 9.\n\nGo to &quot;Code&quot; section and add &quot;openai&quot; to requirements.txt. Your requirements.txt should look like this:\n\n    ask-sdk-core==1.11.0\n    boto3==1.9.216\n    requests&gt;=2.20.0\n\n### 10.\n\nCreate an OpenAI API key on the \u301068\u2020API keys page\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011 by clicking &quot;+ Create new secret key&quot;.\n\n### 11.\n\nReplace your lambda_functions.py file with the \u301071\u2020provided lambda_function.py\u3011.\n\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractExceptionHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractRequestHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.skill_builder import SkillBuilder\n    from ask_sdk_core.handler_input import HandlerInput\n    from ask_sdk_model import Response\n    import ask_sdk_core.utils as ask_utils\n    import requests\n    import logging\n    import json\n\n    # Set your OpenAI API key\n    api_key = &quot;YOUR_API_KEY&quot;\n\n    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\n    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)\n\n    class LaunchRequestHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Skill Launch.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n\n            return ask_utils.is_request_type(&quot;LaunchRequest&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            speak_output = &quot;Chat G.P.T. mode activated&quot;\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .response\n            )\n\n    class GptQueryIntentHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Gpt Query Intent.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n            return ask_utils.is_intent_name(&quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            query = handler_input.request_envelope.request.intent.slots[&quot;query&quot;].value\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            if &quot;chat_history&quot; not in session_attr:\n                session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n            response = generate_gpt_response(session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;], query)\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;].append((query, response))\n\n            return (\n                    handler_input.response_builder\n                        .speak(response)\n                        .ask(&quot;Any other questions?&quot;)\n                        .response\n                )\n\n    class CatchAllExceptionHandler(AbstractExceptionHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; bool\n            return True\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; Response\n            logger.error(exception, exc_info=True)\n\n            speak_output = &quot;Sorry, I had trouble doing what you asked. Please try again.&quot;\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .respons", "title": "GitHub - k4l1sh/alexa-gpt: A tutorial on how to use ChatGPT in Alexa", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": \n\n\u301059\u2020.vscode\u3011\n\n\u301059\u2020.vscode\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020index.js\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020index.js\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020local-debugger.js\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020local-debugger.js\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020package.json\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020package.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020util.js\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020util.js\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020yarn.lock\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020yarn.lock\u3011\n\nView all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n\n# Alexa Skill with ChatGPT\n\nThis repository contains an example of how to use OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model to create an Alexa Skill.\n\n## How it works\n\nThis code connects to the OpenAI ChatGPT API and sends Alexa&#x27;s questions to the model, which processes them and returns the answers. Then, these responses are transmitted back to Alexa and presented to the user.\n\n## Configuration\n\nYou will need to obtain an API key from OpenAI to use the ChatGPT model. More information on how to do this can be found in the OpenAI API documentation.\n\nOnce you have your API key, simply insert it into the index.js file in the designated location.\n\n## Running the example\n\nThis example was developed using Amazon&#x27;s ASK CLI. To run it, you will need to install the ASK CLI and configure your Amazon Developer account.\n\nOnce configured, simply run the following commands in the terminal:\n\n    ask init\n    ask deploy\n\nThis will deploy your Skill to your Amazon Developer account and make it available for use with Alexa.\n\n## Final considerations\n\nThis is just a basic example of how to use ChatGPT with Alexa. You can expand this implementation to create more complex and personalized skills. Enjoy!\n\n## About\n\nThis is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. With it, you can converse naturally with Alexa, answering questions and performing tasks based on its language training. \n\n\u301046\u2020bit.ly/3wUKdIz\u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n### Topics\n\n\u301067\u2020 javascript \u3011 \u301068\u2020 chat \u3011 \u301069\u2020 alexa \u3011 \u301070\u2020 axios \u3011 \u301071\u2020 chat-gpt \u3011 \n\n### Resources\n\nReadme \n\n\u301051\u2020 Activity \u3011 \n\n### Stars\n\n\u301047\u2020 190 stars \u3011 \n\n### Watchers\n\n\u301072\u2020 7 watching \u3011 \n\n### Forks\n\n\u301048\u2020 48 forks \u3011 \n\n\u301073\u2020 Report repository \u3011 \n\n##  \u301074\u2020 Releases \u3011\n\nNo releases published\n\n##  \u301075\u2020 Packages 0 \u3011\n\nNo packages published   \n\n##  \u301076\u2020 Contributors 2 \u3011\n\n  * \u301043\u2020 \u3011  \u30104", "title": "GitHub - Joao208/alexa-chatgpt: This is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n\n# Alexa Skill with ChatGPT\n\nThis repository contains an example of how to use OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model to create an Alexa Skill.\n\n## How it works\n\nThis code connects to the OpenAI ChatGPT API and sends Alexa&#x27;s questions to the model, which processes them and returns the answers. Then, these responses are transmitted back to Alexa and presented to the user.\n\n## Configuration\n\nYou will need to obtain an API key from OpenAI to use the ChatGPT model. More information on how to do this can be found in the OpenAI API documentation.\n\nOnce you have your API key, simply insert it into the index.js file in the designated location.\n\n## Running the example\n\nThis example was developed using Amazon&#x27;s ASK CLI. To run it, you will need to install the ASK CLI and configure your Amazon Developer account.\n\nOnce configured, simply run the following commands in the terminal:\n\n    ask init\n    ask deploy\n\nThis will deploy your Skill to your Amazon Developer account and make it available for use with Alexa.\n\n## Final considerations\n\nThis is just a basic example of how to use ChatGPT with Alexa. You can expand this implementation to create more complex and personalized skills. Enjoy!\n\n## About\n\nThis is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. With it, you can converse naturally with Alexa, answering questions and performing tasks based on its language training. \n\n\u301046\u2020bit.ly/3wUKdIz\u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n### all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n  * MIT license \n\n# Alexa AI\n\n[Image 0: License: MIT]\n\nAzure OpenAI GPT-4.0 will be integrated, and the project is Alexa AI: Boost your Alexa by enhancing its responses. This repository contains a tutorial on how to create a simple Alexa skill that uses the OpenAI API to generate responses from the model.\n\n[Image 1]\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n  * An \u301067\u2020Amazon Developer account\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011\n  * An \u301068\u2020OpenAI API key\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011\n\n## Step-by-step tutorial\n\n### 1. \n\nLog in to your Amazon Developer account and navigate to the \u301069\u2020Alexa Developer Console\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011.\n\n### 2.\n\nClick on &quot;Create Skill&quot; and name the skill &quot;Chat&quot;. Choose the primary locale according to your language.\n\n[Image 2: name your skill]\n\n### 3.\n\nChoose &quot;Other&quot; and &quot;Custom&quot; for the model.\n\n[Image 3: type of experience]\n\n[Image 4: choose a model]\n\n### 4.\n\nChoose &quot;Alexa-hosted (Python)&quot; for the backend resources.\n\n[Image 5: hosting services]\n\n### 5.\n\nYou now have two options:\n\n  * Click on &quot;Import Skill&quot;, paste the link of this repository (\u301070\u2020https://github.com/k4l1sh/alexa-gpt.git\u3011) and click on &quot;Import&quot;. [Image 6: template]\n\nOr if you want to create the skill manually\n\n  * Select &quot;Start from Scratch&quot; and click on &quot;Create Skill&quot;\n\n[Image 7: template]\n\n### 6.\n\nIn the &quot;Build&quot; section, navigate to the &quot;JSON Editor&quot; tab.\n\n### 7.\n\nIf you have directly imported the skill from this repository, just change the &quot;invocationName&quot; to &quot;chat&quot; or another preferred word for activation and proceed to step 12.\n\nHowever, if you chose to manually create the skill, replace the existing JSON content with the \u301065\u2020provided JSON content\u3011:\n\n    {\n        &quot;interactionModel&quot;: {\n            &quot;languageModel&quot;: {\n                &quot;invocationName&quot;: &quot;chat&quot;,\n                &quot;intents&quot;: [\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;slots&quot;: [\n                            {\n                                &quot;name&quot;: &quot;query&quot;,\n                                &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.Person&quot;\n                            }\n                        ],\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: [\n                            &quot;{query}&quot;\n                        ]\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.NavigateHomeIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    }\n                ],\n                &quot;types&quot;: []\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n[Image 8: json_editor]\n\n### 8.\n\nSave the model and click on &quot;Build Model&quot;.\n\n### 9.\n\nGo to &quot;Code&quot; section and add &quot;openai&quot; to requirements.txt. Your requirements.txt should look like this:\n\n    ask-sdk-core==1.11.0\n    boto3==1.9.216\n    requests&gt;=2.20.0\n\n### 10.\n\nCreate an OpenAI API key on the \u301068\u2020API keys page\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011 by clicking &quot;+ Create new secret key&quot;.\n\n### 11.\n\nReplace your lambda_functions.py file with the \u301071\u2020provided lambda_function.py\u3011.\n\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractExceptionHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractRequestHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.skill_builder import SkillBuilder\n    from ask_sdk_core.handler_input import HandlerInput\n    from ask_sdk_model import Response\n    import ask_sdk_core.utils as ask_utils\n    import requests\n    import logging\n    import json\n\n    # Set your OpenAI API key\n    api_key = &quot;YOUR_API_KEY&quot;\n\n    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\n    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)\n\n    class LaunchRequestHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Skill Launch.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n\n            return ask_utils.is_request_type(&quot;LaunchRequest&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            speak_output = &quot;Chat G.P.T. mode activated&quot;\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .response\n            )\n\n    class GptQueryIntentHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Gpt Query Intent.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n            return ask_utils.is_intent_name(&quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            query = handler_input.request_envelope.request.intent.slots[&quot;query&quot;].value\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            if &quot;chat_history&quot; not in session_attr:\n                session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n            response = generate_gpt_response(session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;], query)\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;].append((query, response))\n\n            return (\n                    handler_input.response_builder\n                        .speak(response)\n                        .ask(&quot;Any other questions?&quot;)\n                        .response\n                )\n\n    class CatchAllExceptionHandler(AbstractExceptionHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; bool\n            return True\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input,", "title": "GitHub - bsab/Alexa-AI-Skill", &quot;Build&quot; section, navigate to the &quot;JSON Editor&quot; tab.\n\n### 7.\n\nIf you have directly imported the skill from this repository, just change the &quot;invocationName&quot; to &quot;chat&quot; or another preferred word for activation and proceed to step 12.\n\nHowever, if you chose to manually create the skill, replace the existing JSON content with the \u301065\u2020provided JSON content\u3011:\n\n    {\n        &quot;interactionModel&quot;: {\n            &quot;languageModel&quot;: {\n                &quot;invocationName&quot;: &quot;chat&quot;,\n                &quot;intents&quot;: [\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;slots&quot;: [\n                            {\n                                &quot;name&quot;: &quot;query&quot;,\n                                &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.Person&quot;\n                            }\n                        ],\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: [\n                            &quot;{query}&quot;\n                        ]\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.NavigateHomeIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    }\n                ],\n                &quot;types&quot;: []\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n[Image 8: json_editor]\n\n### 8.\n\nSave the model and click on &quot;Build Model&quot;.\n\n### 9.\n\nGo to &quot;Code&quot; section and add &quot;openai&quot; to requirements.txt. Your requirements.txt should look like this:\n\n    ask-sdk-core==1.11.0\n    boto3==1.9.216\n    requests&gt;=2.20.0\n\n### 10.\n\nCreate an OpenAI API key on the \u301068\u2020API keys page\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011 by clicking &quot;+ Create new secret key&quot;.\n\n### 11.\n\nReplace your lambda_functions.py file with the \u301071\u2020provided lambda_function.py\u3011.\n\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractExceptionHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractRequestHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.skill_builder import SkillBuilder\n    from ask_sdk_core.handler_input import HandlerInput\n    from ask_sdk_model import Response\n    import ask_sdk_core.utils as ask_utils\n    import requests\n    import logging\n    import json\n\n    # Set your OpenAI API key\n    api_key = &quot;YOUR_API_KEY&quot;\n\n    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\n    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)\n\n    class LaunchRequestHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Skill Launch.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n\n            return ask_utils.is_request_type(&quot;LaunchRequest&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            speak_output = &quot;Chat G.P.T. mode activated&quot;\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .response\n            )\n\n    class GptQueryIntentHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Gpt Query Intent.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n            return ask_utils.is_intent_name(&quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            query = handler_input.request_envelope.request.intent.slots[&quot;query&quot;].value\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            if &quot;chat_history&quot; not in session_attr:\n                session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n            response = generate_gpt_response(session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;], query)\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;].append((query, response))\n\n            return (\n                    handler_input.response_builder\n                        .speak(response)\n                        .ask(&quot;Any other questions?&quot;)\n                        .response\n                )\n\n    class CatchAllExceptionHandler(AbstractExceptionHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; bool\n            return True\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input,", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 8, 16]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "5b2e0d3a-84a3-4e2d-af97-a4bc13f12f95", "request_id": "8d1fb9c0887abadf-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5b2e0d3a-84a3-4e2d-af97-a4bc13f12f95", "children": ["cc71f4b3-541b-40e9-9a3f-e386a87c95d6"]}, "cc71f4b3-541b-40e9-9a3f-e386a87c95d6": { "message": { "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1728826675.305326, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Yes, there are open-source repositories that can help you integrate OpenAI with Alexa quickly. You can set it up by modifying the existing code to include your OpenAI API key. The repository provides all the necessary components to get started with creating an Alexa Skill that can leverage OpenAI\u2019s responses. You can find more about this project [here on GitHub](https://github.com/Joao208/alexa-chatgpt)\u301089\u2020source\u3011.\n\n2. **bsab/Alexa-AI-Skill**: This repository demonstrates how to build an Alexa skill that uses OpenAI\u2019s GPT models. It includes step-by-step instructions on setting up the skill in the Alexa Developer Console and integrating OpenAI API calls within the lambda function. You just need to plug in your API key and follow the setup process. all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n\n# Alexa Skill with ChatGPT\n\nThis repository contains an example of how to use OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model to create an Alexa Skill.\n\n## How it works\n\nThis code connects to the OpenAI ChatGPT API and sends Alexa&#x27;s questions to the model, which processes them and returns the answers. Then, these responses are transmitted back to Alexa and presented to the user.\n\n## Configuration\n\nYou will need to obtain an API key from OpenAI to use the ChatGPT model. More information on how to do this can be found in the OpenAI API documentation.\n\nOnce you have your API key, simply insert it into the index.js file in the designated location.\n\n## Running the example\n\nThis example was developed using Amazon&#x27;s ASK CLI. To run it, you will need to install the ASK CLI and configure your Amazon Developer account.\n\nOnce configured, simply run the following commands in the terminal:\n\n    ask init\n    ask deploy\n\nThis will deploy your Skill to your Amazon Developer account and make it available for use with Alexa.\n\n## Final considerations\n\nThis is just a basic example of how to use ChatGPT with Alexa. You can expand this implementation to create more complex and personalized skills. Enjoy!\n\n## About\n\nThis is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. With it, you can converse naturally with Alexa, answering questions and performing tasks based on its language training. \n\n\u301046\u2020bit.ly/3wUKdIz\u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n### Topics\n\n\u301067\u2020 javascript \u3011 \u301068\u2020 chat \u3011 \u301069\u2020 alexa \u3011 \u301070\u2020 axios \u3011 \u301071\u2020 chat-gpt \u3011 \n\n### Resources\n\nReadme \n\n\u301051\u2020 Activity \u3011 \n\n### Stars\n\n\u301047\u2020 190 stars \u3011 \n\n### Watchers\n\n\u301072\u2020 7 watching \u3011 \n\n### Forks\n\n\u301048\u2020 48 forks \u3011 \n\n\u301073\u2020 Report repository \u3011 \n\n##  \u301074\u2020 Releases \u3011\n\nNo releases published\n\n##  \u301075\u2020 Packages 0 \u3011\n\nNo packages published   \n\n##  \u301076\u2020 Contributors 2 \u3011\n\n  * \u301043\u2020 \u3011  \u30104", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 89, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 969, "end_ix": 980, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "GitHub - This repository contains a tutorial on how to create a simple Alexa skill that uses the OpenAI API to generate responses from the model.\n\n[Image 1]\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n  * An \u301067\u2020Amazon Developer account\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011\n  * An \u301068\u2020OpenAI API key\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011\n\n## Step-by-step tutorial\n\n### 1. \n\nLog in to your Amazon Developer account and navigate to the \u301069\u2020Alexa Developer Console\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011.\n\n### 2.\n\nClick on &quot;Create Skill&quot; and name the skill &quot;Chat&quot;. Choose the primary locale according to your language.\n\n[Image 2: name your skill]\n\n### 3.\n\nChoose &quot;Other&quot; and &quot;Custom&quot; for the model.\n\n[Image 3: type of experience]\n\n[Image 4: choose a model]\n\n### 4.\n\nChoose &quot;Alexa-hosted (Python)&quot; for the backend resources.\n\n[Image 5: hosting services]\n\n### 5.\n\nYou now have two options:\n\n  * Click on &quot;Import Skill&quot;, paste the link of this repository (\u301070\u2020https://github.com/k4l1sh/alexa-gpt.git\u3011) and click on &quot;Import&quot;. [Image 6: template]\n\nOr if you want to create the skill manually\n\n  * Select &quot;Start from Scratch&quot; and click on &quot;Create Skill&quot;\n\n[Image 7: template]\n\n### 6.\n\nIn the &quot;Build&quot; section, navigate to the &quot;JSON Editor&quot; tab.\n\n### 7.\n\nIf you have directly imported the skill from this repository, just change the &quot;invocationName&quot; to &quot;chat&quot; or another preferred word for activation and proceed to step 12.\n\nHowever, if you chose to manually create the skill, replace the existing JSON content with the \u301065\u2020provided JSON content\u3011:\n\n    {\n        &quot;interactionModel&quot;: {\n            &quot;languageModel&quot;: {\n                &quot;invocationName&quot;: &quot;chat&quot;,\n                &quot;intents&quot;: [\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;slots&quot;: [\n                            {\n                                &quot;name&quot;: &quot;query&quot;,\n                                &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.Person&quot;\n                            }\n                        ],\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: [\n                            &quot;{query}&quot;\n                        ]\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.NavigateHomeIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    }\n                ],\n                &quot;types&quot;: []\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n[Image 8: json_editor]\n\n### 8.\n\nSave the model and click on &quot;Build Model&quot;.\n\n### 9.\n\nGo to &quot;Code&quot; section and add &quot;openai&quot; to requirements.txt. Your requirements.txt should look like this:\n\n    ask-sdk-core==1.11.0\n    boto3==1.9.216\n    requests&gt;=2.20.0\n\n### 10.\n\nCreate an OpenAI API key on the \u301068\u2020API keys page\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011 by clicking &quot;+ Create new secret key&quot;.\n\n### 11.\n\nReplace your lambda_functions.py file with the \u301071\u2020provided lambda_function.py\u3011.\n\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractExceptionHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractRequestHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.skill_builder import SkillBuilder\n    from ask_sdk_core.handler_input import HandlerInput\n    from ask_sdk_model import Response\n    import ask_sdk_core.utils as ask_utils\n    import requests\n    import logging\n    import json\n\n    # Set your OpenAI API key\n    api_key = &quot;YOUR_API_KEY&quot;\n\n    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\n    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)\n\n    class LaunchRequestHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Skill Launch.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n\n            return ask_utils.is_request_type(&quot;LaunchRequest&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            speak_output = &quot;Chat G.P.T. mode activated&quot;\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .response\n            )\n\n    class GptQueryIntentHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Gpt Query Intent.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n            return ask_utils.is_intent_name(&quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            query = handler_input.request_envelope.request.intent.slots[&quot;query&quot;].value\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            if &quot;chat_history&quot; not in session_attr:\n                session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n            response = generate_gpt_response(session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;], query)\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;].append((query, response))\n\n            return (\n                    handler_input.response_builder\n                        .speak(response)\n                        .ask(&quot;Any other questions?&quot;)\n                        .response\n                )\n\n    class CatchAllExceptionHandler(AbstractExceptionHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; bool\n            return True\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input,", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 90, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u301089\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 549, "end_idx": 560, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "GitHub - Joao208/alexa-chatgpt: This is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. \n\n\u301059\u2020.vscode\u3011\n\n\u301059\u2020.vscode\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020index.js\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020index.js\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020local-debugger.js\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020local-debugger.js\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020package.json\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020package.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020util.js\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020util.js\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020yarn.lock\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020yarn.lock\u3011\n\nView all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n\n# Alexa Skill with ChatGPT\n\nThis repository contains an example of how to use OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model to create an Alexa Skill.\n\n## How it works\n\nThis code connects to the OpenAI ChatGPT API and sends Alexa&#x27;s questions to the model, which processes them and returns the answers. Then, these responses are transmitted back to Alexa and presented to the user.\n\n## Configuration\n\nYou will need to obtain an API key from OpenAI to use the ChatGPT model. More information on how to do this can be found in the OpenAI API documentation.\n\nOnce you have your API key, simply insert it into the index.js file in the designated location.\n\n## Running the example\n\nThis example was developed using Amazon&#x27;s ASK CLI. To run it, you will need to install the ASK CLI and configure your Amazon Developer account.\n\nOnce configured, simply run the following commands in the terminal:\n\n    ask init\n    ask deploy\n\nThis will deploy your Skill to your Amazon Developer account and make it available for use with Alexa.\n\n## Final considerations\n\nThis is just a basic example of how to use ChatGPT with Alexa. You can expand this implementation to create more complex and personalized skills. Enjoy!\n\n## About\n\nThis is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. With it, you can converse naturally with Alexa, answering questions and performing tasks based on its language training. \n\n\u301046\u2020bit.ly/3wUKdIz\u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n### Topics\n\n\u301067\u2020 javascript \u3011 \u301068\u2020 chat \u3011 \u301069\u2020 alexa \u3011 \u301070\u2020 axios \u3011 \u301071\u2020 chat-gpt \u3011 \n\n### Resources\n\nReadme \n\n\u301051\u2020 Activity \u3011 \n\n### Stars\n\n\u301047\u2020 190 stars \u3011 \n\n### Watchers\n\n\u301072\u2020 7 watching \u3011 \n\n### Forks\n\n\u301048\u2020 48 forks \u3011 \n\n\u301073\u2020 Report repository \u3011 \n\n##  \u301074\u2020 Releases \u3011\n\nNo releases published\n\n##  \u301075\u2020 Packages 0 \u3011\n\nNo packages published   \n\n##  \u301076\u2020 Contributors 2 \u3011\n\n  * \u301043\u2020 \u3011  \u30104"}, {"matched_text": "\u301090\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 969, "end_idx": 980, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "GitHub - bsab/Alexa-AI-Skill", "url": "https://github.com/bsab/Alexa-AI-Skill", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "  * \u301053\u2020 Pull requests 0 \u3011\n  * \u301054\u2020 Actions \u3011\n  * \u301055\u2020 Projects 0 \u3011\n  * \u301056\u2020 Security \u3011\n  * \u301057\u2020 Insights \u3011\n\n  Additional navigation options  \n\n  * \u301044\u2020 Code \u3011 \n  * \u301052\u2020 Issues \u3011 \n  * \u301053\u2020 Pull requests \u3011 \n  * \u301054\u2020 Actions \u3011 \n  * \u301055\u2020 Projects \u3011 \n  * \u301056\u2020 Security \u3011 \n  * \u301057\u2020 Insights \u3011 \n\n# bsab/Alexa-AI-Skill\n\nThis commit does not belong to any branch on this repository, and may belong to a fork outside of the repository.\n\n\u00a0main\n\n\u301049\u2020Branches\u3011\u301050\u2020Tags\u3011\n\nGo to file \n\nCode\n\n## Folders and files \n\nName Name \n\nLast commit message \n\nLast commit date   \n\n## Latest commit\n\n## History\n\n\u301058\u20205 Commits\u3011  \n\n\u301059\u2020images\u3011\n\n\u301059\u2020images\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020lambda\u3011\n\n\u301060\u2020lambda\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020models\u3011\n\n\u301061\u2020models\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301062\u2020.gitignore\u3011\n\n\u301046\u2020LICENSE\u3011\n\n\u301046\u2020LICENSE\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301063\u2020README.md\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020ask-resources.json\u3011\n\n\u301064\u2020ask-resources.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020json_editor.json\u3011\n\n\u301065\u2020json_editor.json\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020skill.json\u3011\n\n\u301066\u2020skill.json\u3011\n\nView all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n  * MIT license \n\n# Alexa AI\n\n[Image 0: License: MIT]\n\nAzure OpenAI GPT-4.0 will be integrated, and the project is Alexa AI: Boost your Alexa by enhancing its responses. This repository contains a tutorial on how to create a simple Alexa skill that uses the OpenAI API to generate responses from the model.\n\n[Image 1]\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n  * An \u301067\u2020Amazon Developer account\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011\n  * An \u301068\u2020OpenAI API key\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011\n\n## Step-by-step tutorial\n\n### 1. \n\nLog in to your Amazon Developer account and navigate to the \u301069\u2020Alexa Developer Console\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011.\n\n### 2.\n\nClick on &quot;Create Skill&quot; and name the skill &quot;Chat&quot;. Choose the primary locale according to your language.\n\n[Image 2: name your skill]\n\n### 3.\n\nChoose &quot;Other&quot; and &quot;Custom&quot; for the model.\n\n[Image 3: type of experience]\n\n[Image 4: choose a model]\n\n### 4.\n\nChoose &quot;Alexa-hosted (Python)&quot; for the backend resources.\n\n[Image 5: hosting services]\n\n### 5.\n\nYou now have two options:\n\n  * Click on &quot;Import Skill&quot;, paste the link of this repository (\u301070\u2020https://github.com/k4l1sh/alexa-gpt.git\u3011) and click on &quot;Import&quot;. [Image 6: template]\n\nOr if you want to create the skill manually\n\n  * Select &quot;Start from Scratch&quot; and click on &quot;Create Skill&quot;\n\n[Image 7: template]\n\n### 6.\n\nIn the &quot;Build&quot; section, navigate to the &quot;JSON Editor&quot; tab.\n\n### 7.\n\nIf you have directly imported the skill from this repository, just change the &quot;invocationName&quot; to &quot;chat&quot; or another preferred word for activation and proceed to step 12.\n\nHowever, if you chose to manually create the skill, replace the existing JSON content with the \u301065\u2020provided JSON content\u3011:\n\n    {\n        &quot;interactionModel&quot;: {\n            &quot;languageModel&quot;: {\n                &quot;invocationName&quot;: &quot;chat&quot;,\n                &quot;intents&quot;: [\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;slots&quot;: [\n                            {\n                                &quot;name&quot;: &quot;query&quot;,\n                                &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.Person&quot;\n                            }\n                        ],\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: [\n                            &quot;{query}&quot;\n                        ]\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    },\n                    {\n                        &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AMAZON.NavigateHomeIntent&quot;,\n                        &quot;samples&quot;: []\n                    }\n                ],\n                &quot;types&quot;: []\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\n[Image 8: json_editor]\n\n### 8.\n\nSave the model and click on &quot;Build Model&quot;.\n\n### 9.\n\nGo to &quot;Code&quot; section and add &quot;openai&quot; to requirements.txt. Your requirements.txt should look like this:\n\n    ask-sdk-core==1.11.0\n    boto3==1.9.216\n    requests&gt;=2.20.0\n\n### 10.\n\nCreate an OpenAI API key on the \u301068\u2020API keys page\u2020platform.openai.com\u3011 by clicking &quot;+ Create new secret key&quot;.\n\n### 11.\n\nReplace your lambda_functions.py file with the \u301071\u2020provided lambda_function.py\u3011.\n\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractExceptionHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.dispatch_components import AbstractRequestHandler\n    from ask_sdk_core.skill_builder import SkillBuilder\n    from ask_sdk_core.handler_input import HandlerInput\n    from ask_sdk_model import Response\n    import ask_sdk_core.utils as ask_utils\n    import requests\n    import logging\n    import json\n\n    # Set your OpenAI API key\n    api_key = &quot;YOUR_API_KEY&quot;\n\n    logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\n    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)\n\n    class LaunchRequestHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Skill Launch.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n\n            return ask_utils.is_request_type(&quot;LaunchRequest&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            speak_output = &quot;Chat G.P.T. mode activated&quot;\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n\n            return (\n                handler_input.response_builder\n                    .speak(speak_output)\n                    .ask(speak_output)\n                    .response\n            )\n\n    class GptQueryIntentHandler(AbstractRequestHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Handler for Gpt Query Intent.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; bool\n            return ask_utils.is_intent_name(&quot;GptQueryIntent&quot;)(handler_input)\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input):\n            # type: (HandlerInput) -&gt; Response\n            query = handler_input.request_envelope.request.intent.slots[&quot;query&quot;].value\n\n            session_attr = handler_input.attributes_manager.session_attributes\n            if &quot;chat_history&quot; not in session_attr:\n                session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;] = []\n            response = generate_gpt_response(session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;], query)\n            session_attr[&quot;chat_history&quot;].append((query, response))\n\n            return (\n                    handler_input.response_builder\n                        .speak(response)\n                        .ask(&quot;Any other questions?&quot;)\n                        .response\n                )\n\n    class CatchAllExceptionHandler(AbstractExceptionHandler):\n        &quot;&quot;&quot;Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors.&quot;&quot;&quot;\n        def can_handle(self, handler_input, exception):\n            # type: (HandlerInput, Exception) -&gt; bool\n            return True\n\n        def handle(self, handler_input,"}], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "f4dfc757-99ea-4881-bd4b-bc2bdae243a8", "request_id": "8d1fb9c0887abadf-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "f4dfc757-99ea-4881-bd4b-bc2bdae243a8", "children": ["aaa227ec-dd61-4e1d-94f8-77c0b3e15a55"]}, "aaa227ec-dd61-4e1d-94f8-77c0b3e15a55": { "message": { "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1728826727.347502, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["which one is best for lazy fringe coders like me? all files   \n\n## Repository files navigation \n\n  * README \n\n# Alexa Skill with ChatGPT\n\nThis repository contains an example of how to use OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model to create an Alexa Skill.\n\n## How it works\n\nThis code connects to the OpenAI ChatGPT API and sends Alexa&#x27;s questions to the model, which processes them and returns the answers. Then, these responses are transmitted back to Alexa and presented to the user.\n\n## Configuration\n\nYou will need to obtain an API key from OpenAI to use the ChatGPT model. More information on how to do this can be found in the OpenAI API documentation.\n\nOnce you have your API key, simply insert it into the index.js file in the designated location.\n\n## Running the example\n\nThis example was developed using Amazon&#x27;s ASK CLI. To run it, you will need to install the ASK CLI and configure your Amazon Developer account.\n\nOnce configured, simply run the following commands in the terminal:\n\n    ask init\n    ask deploy\n\nThis will deploy your Skill to your Amazon Developer account and make it available for use with Alexa.\n\n## Final considerations\n\nThis is just a basic example of how to use ChatGPT with Alexa. You can expand this implementation to create more complex and personalized skills. Enjoy!\n\n## About\n\nThis is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. With it, you can converse naturally with Alexa, answering questions and performing tasks based on its language training. \n\n\u301046\u2020bit.ly/3wUKdIz\u2020bit.ly\u3011 \n\n### Topics\n\n\u301067\u2020 javascript \u3011 \u301068\u2020 chat \u3011 \u301069\u2020 alexa \u3011 \u301070\u2020 axios \u3011 \u301071\u2020 chat-gpt \u3011 \n\n### Resources\n\nReadme \n\n\u301051\u2020 Activity \u3011 \n\n### Stars\n\n\u301047\u2020 190 stars \u3011 \n\n### Watchers\n\n\u301072\u2020 7 watching \u3011 \n\n### Forks\n\n\u301048\u2020 48 forks \u3011 \n\n\u301073\u2020 Report repository \u3011 \n\n##  \u301074\u2020 Releases \u3011\n\nNo releases published\n\n##  \u301075\u2020 Packages 0 \u3011\n\nNo packages published   \n\n##  \u301076\u2020 Contributors 2 \u3011\n\n  * \u301043\u2020 \u3011  \u30104", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 89, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u301089\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 944, "end_idx": 955, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "GitHub - Joao208/alexa-chatgpt: This is an Alexa bot developed with the help of OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT language model. These licenses often allow modification and even commercialization, but with certain conditions. For example:\n   - **MIT License**: This is very permissive and typically allows for commercial use, provided that you include the original copyright notice and license in your project.\n   - **GPL**: This requires that if you modify and distribute the software, you must also open-source your version under the same license.\n\n   **What to do**: Check the repository&#x27;s license (which is usually included in the project) to ensure you comply with its terms before monetizing anything based on it.\n\n### 2. **Attribution**:  \nIn some cases, even if monetization is allowed, you are required to give proper credit to the original creator. Failing to do so can be seen as dishonest or shady. Be transparent about the use of open-source code and clearly state your modifications or contributions if you are selling or monetizing the skill.\n\n### 3. **Ethical Considerations**:  \nUsing someone else\u2019s open-source work for commercial gain without adding substantial value or giving credit can be perceived as taking advantage of the community. It&#x27;s important to ask yourself:\n   - Are you adding unique value to the product, or is it just a repackaged version of someone else&#x27;s work?\n   - Would the original author approve of your monetization efforts?\n\n   If you&#x27;re mostly using the open-source work without significant changes, it\u2019s more ethical to either refrain from monetizing or to contribute back to the project (e.g., through donations, code contributions, or support).\n\n### 4. **User Expectations**:  \nIf you charge users for a skill, they will expect high reliability, support, and ongoing updates. If the core functionality relies on a third-party open-source project, you\u2019ll need to ensure that it\u2019s stable and properly supported. Otherwise, users may see this as shady or a ripoff if issues arise, especially if they find out it\u2019s built on open-source software.\n\n### 5. **Reputational Risk**:  \nWhile not necessarily dishonest, monetizing something that heavily relies on open-source contributions can give the impression of being opportunistic if not handled transparently. However, if you build upon the open-source code, add significant improvements, and provide value beyond what\u2019s already freely available, this risk is mitigated.\n\n### Final Thought:\nMonetizing your Alexa skill can be done ethically as long as you:\n   - Follow the license terms.\n   - Give credit where it\u2019s due.\n   - Provide value beyond what the open-source project offers.\n   - Ensure users know what they\u2019re paying for.\n\nIf you handle it transparently and add value, there\u2019s no reason why it would be considered shady. However, failing to follow these guidelines could hurt your reputation."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

The ASK CLI lets you manage your Alexa skills. \n   - To install ASK CLI, run the following command in your terminal:\n     ```bash\n     npm install -g ask-cli\n     ```\n\n2. **Clone the Repository**:\n   - Go to the GitHub repository page [Joao208/alexa-chatgpt](https://github.com/Joao208/alexa-chatgpt) and click on the **Code** button.\n   - Copy the URL from the HTTPS or SSH section.\n   - In your terminal or command prompt, navigate to the directory where you want to store the project, then run the following command:\n     ```bash\n     git clone https://github.com/Joao208/alexa-chatgpt.git\n     ```\n   - This will download the repository onto your local machine.\n\n3. **Open the Project Folder**:\n   - Navigate to the downloaded project directory:\n     ```bash\n     cd alexa-chatgpt\n     ```\n\n4. **Open the `index.js` File**:\n   - In this project folder, find the `index.js` file, which contains the core logic for the Alexa skill.\n   - You\u2019ll need to modify this file to include your OpenAI API key.\n   - Open the file in any text editor (VSCode, Sublime Text, etc.) and look for the section where you should input your OpenAI API key (usually something like `const openAiApiKey = &#x27;YOUR_API_KEY&#x27;;`).\n   - Replace `&#x27;YOUR_API_KEY&#x27;` with your actual OpenAI API key.\n\n5. **Update Dependencies**:\n   - Install the required dependencies for the project by running:\n     ```bash\n     npm install\n     ```\n\n6. **Configure ASK CLI**:\n   - Run the following command to initialize ASK CLI:\n     ```bash\n     ask init\n     ```\n   - Follow the on-screen prompts to authenticate and configure your Amazon developer account.\n\n7. **Deploy the Skill**:\n   - Once everything is set up, you can deploy the skill to your Amazon Developer account by running:\n     ```bash\n     ask deploy\n     ```\n\n8. **Test the Skill**:\n   - After deploying, you can test your skill using the Alexa developer console or any Alexa-enabled device.\n   - You can also test it locally by using the `local-debugger.js` file provided in the repository. You\u2019ll need to set up a local debugging environment using Node.js.\n\n9. **Modify and Expand the Skill (Optional)**:\n   - The project you\u2019ve cloned is a basic template for Alexa to interact with ChatGPT. It\u2019s similar to package managers like `apt` on Linux or `Homebrew` on macOS. Chocolatey automates the process of downloading, installing, and configuring software on Windows systems by using simple commands.\n\n### Why Use Chocolatey?\n- **Automated Installations:** Chocolatey allows you to install software with a single command, saving you time from manually downloading and running installers.\n- **Easily Manage Packages:** You can update or remove software in bulk.\n- **Wide Range of Software:** Chocolatey supports many popular programs, libraries, and tools, including development environments like Node.js, Docker, and Visual Studio Code.\n\n### Example of Installing Node.js with Chocolatey:\nOnce you have Chocolatey installed, you can install Node.js (and npm, which comes with it) by running:\n```powershell\nchoco install nodejs\n```\n\n### How to Install Chocolatey:\n1. It won\u2019t corrupt your system as long as you:\n\n1. **Do not remove existing paths:** Just add a new entry without deleting or altering the other ones. You are simply telling the system where to find additional programs.\n\n2. **Double-check the path you&#x27;re adding:** Make sure the path is correct. Based on your screenshot, it should be:\n   ```\n   C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\\n   ```\n\nHere are some key points:\n- **What is the `Path` variable?** It tells your system where to find executable programs like `node` and `npm`. PowerShell has an execution policy that controls the ability to run scripts and can sometimes block the execution of commands like `ask --version`.\n\nHere\u2019s how you can fix this:\n\n1. **Open PowerShell as Administrator**: \n   - Right-click the **Start** menu and select **Windows PowerShell (Admin)** to open an elevated PowerShell window.\n\n2. **Check Current Execution Policy**:\n   - Run this command to check the current execution policy:\n     ```bash\n     Get-ExecutionPolicy\n     ```\n   - If it returns `Restricted`, it means scripts are blocked.\n\n3. **Set the Execution Policy**:\n   - To allow the execution of scripts, run the following command:\n     ```bash\n     Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser\n     ```\n   - This command sets the execution policy to `RemoteSigned`, which allows scripts to run locally (i.e., scripts created on your computer). Any scripts downloaded from the internet will need to be signed by a trusted publisher.\n\n4. **Confirm the Policy Change**:\n   - When prompted, type `Y` to confirm the change.\n\n5. **Try Running the `ask` Command Again**:\n   - Once you&#x27;ve set the execution policy, try running the `ask --version` command again to check if it works.\n\nIf this process completes successfully, you should be able to run your Alexa Skill CLI commands without further issues.\n\nLet me know how it goes!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

If your Alexa skill requires dynamic content (e.g., making API requests), this might not be the best choice.\n\n   [Visit GitHub Pages](https://pages.github.com/)\n\n### 3. **Replit**\n   - **No credit card required**: Replit offers free hosting and an integrated development environment (IDE). You can build, test, and deploy small applications without providing billing information.\n   - **Limitations**: Free plans have some limitations in terms of CPU and memory, but it\u2019s good for small-scale projects or testing.\n\n   [Visit Replit](https://replit.com/)\n\n### 4. **Vercel**\n   - **No credit card required initially**: Vercel provides a generous free tier, and you can deploy projects without giving credit card information upfront. \n   - **Limitations**: Vercel\u2019s free plan is good for small to medium projects, but you will need to upgrade if your usage grows significantly.\n\n   [Visit Vercel](https://vercel.com/)\n\n### 5. **Netlify**\n   - **No credit card required**: Netlify offers free hosting for static sites, similar to GitHub Pages, but with additional features like form handling and continuous deployment.\n   - **Limitations**: Like GitHub Pages, it works well for static sites. Dynamic content may require more complex workarounds.\n\n   [Visit Netlify](https://www.netlify.com/)\n\nIf you are looking for a solution where you can avoid providing billing details entirely, **Glitch** and **Replit** are the most suitable options for small-scale Alexa Skill development with a free backend.\n\nLet me know if you&#x27;d like guidance on how to get started with any of these platforms!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Now that you&#x27;re on Glitch, let&#x27;s get your Alexa Skill running there. Here&#x27;s a step-by-step guide to follow:\n\n### Step 1: Create a New Project\n1. Go to [Glitch](https://glitch.com/).\n2. On the homepage, click **&quot;New Project&quot;**.\n3. Select **&quot;Create a Node App&quot;** since your Alexa Skill will use Node.js to communicate with the OpenAI API.\n\n### Step 2: Set Up Your Project Environment\n1. Once the project is created, you&#x27;ll see some files like `package.json`, `server.js`, etc.\n2. Rename **`server.js`** to **`index.js`**, as that&#x27;s where you will place your code.\n3. Open the **`package.json`** file, and add any necessary dependencies. You will need `axios` to make HTTP requests to OpenAI&#x27;s API. It should look something like this:\n\n   ```json\n   {\n     &quot;name&quot;: &quot;alexa-chatgpt&quot;,\n     &quot;version&quot;: &quot;1.0.0&quot;,\n     &quot;description&quot;: &quot;Alexa Skill powered by OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT&quot;,\n     &quot;main&quot;: &quot;index.js&quot;,\n     &quot;scripts&quot;: {\n       &quot;start&quot;: &quot;node index.js&quot;\n     },\n     &quot;dependencies&quot;: {\n       &quot;express&quot;: &quot;^4.17.1&quot;,\n       &quot;axios&quot;: &quot;^0.21.1&quot;\n     }\n   }\n   ```\n\n4. After you modify `package.json`, Glitch will automatically install the necessary dependencies.\n\n### Step 3: Write the Alexa Skill Code\n1. In **`index.js`**, write the basic Express server setup:\n\n   ```js\n   const express = require(&#x27;express&#x27;);\n   const axios = require(&#x27;axios&#x27;);\n   const app = express();\n\n   app.use(express.json());\n\n   app.post(&#x27;/alexa&#x27;, async (req, res) =&gt; {\n       const alexaRequest = req.body;\n       const userQuery = alexaRequest.request.intent.slots.query.value;\n\n       try {\n           // Make a request to OpenAI API\n           const openAIResponse = await axios.post(\n               &#x27;https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions&#x27;,\n               {\n                   model: &quot;gpt-3.5-turbo&quot;,\n                   messages: [{ role: &quot;user&quot;, content: userQuery }]\n               },\n               {\n                   headers: {\n                       &#x27;Authorization&#x27;: `Bearer YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY`,\n                       &#x27;Content-Type&#x27;: &#x27;application/json&#x27;\n                   }\n               }\n           );\n\n           const aiResponse = openAIResponse.data.choices[0].message.content;\n\n           // Construct a response for Alexa\n           res.json({\n               version: &#x27;1.0&#x27;,\n               response: {\n                   outputSpeech: {\n                       type: &#x27;PlainText&#x27;,\n                       text: aiResponse,\n                   },\n                   shouldEndSession: true,\n               }\n           });\n       } catch (error) {\n           console.error(error);\n           res.status(500).json({ error: &quot;Something went wrong&quot; });\n       }\n   });\n\n   // Start the server\n   const PORT = process.env.PORT || 3000;\n   app.listen(PORT, () =&gt; {\n       console.log(`Server is running on port ${PORT}`);\n   });\n   ```\n\n2. Replace **`YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY`** with your actual OpenAI API key.\n\n### Step 4: Configure Alexa to Use Your Glitch App\n1. Once the code is working, click **&quot;Share&quot;** in the Glitch project and copy the live link (the URL that ends with `glitch.me`).\n2. Go to the [Alexa Developer Console](https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask) and set up a new Alexa Skill.\n3. In the **&quot;Endpoint&quot;** section of the Alexa Developer Console, paste the **Glitch URL** followed by `/alexa` (e.g., `https://yourprojectname.glitch.me/alexa`).\n\n### Step 5: Test Your Alexa Skill\n1. Use the Alexa Developer Console to test the skill by typing or speaking a request to Alexa.\n2. Your Glitch server will receive the request, process it with OpenAI, and return the response to Alexa.\n\n### Step 6: Make Sure the Server Keeps Running\nTo ensure the server doesn&#x27;t go to sleep, you may want to set up a ping service like [UptimeRobot](https://uptimerobot.com/) to periodically ping your Glitch URL.\n\nLet me know if you need help with any of these steps!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here&#x27;s how to proceed:\n\n### Step-by-Step Guide to Using Glitch for Your Alexa Skill\n\n1. **Create a Project on Glitch**:\n   - Go to [Glitch](https://glitch.com/).\n   - Create a new project by clicking on \u201cNew Project\u201d and choosing a template, such as the &quot;Hello Node&quot; project.\n   - This will give you a basic Node.js server, which you can edit for your Alexa skill.\n\n2. **Clone or Fork the GitHub Repository**:\n   - Go to the GitHub repository (such as the one you were initially using), copy the code, and paste it into the relevant sections of your Glitch project.\n   - Alternatively, you can &quot;Import from GitHub&quot; directly in Glitch if you&#x27;re more comfortable using GitHub for version control.\n\n3. **Set Up the OpenAI API**:\n   - Open the `index.js` or any relevant file in the project. Here, you will need to insert your **OpenAI API key**.\n   - You can replace any placeholder keys with your real OpenAI API key, which you should have already set up in earlier steps.\n   - The OpenAI key usually goes in a part of the code that interacts with the API (e.g., using the `axios` library or another HTTP request package).\n\n4. **Configure the Alexa Skill Interaction**:\n   - Ensure that the code handles incoming Alexa requests correctly. In the file handling the Alexa skill&#x27;s logic (usually `index.js` or similar), make sure it sends the response from ChatGPT back to the Alexa device.\n   - You\u2019ll also want to check that the request format Alexa sends matches what your server expects. Adjust as needed to ensure smooth communication.\n\n5. **Deploy Your Glitch Project**:\n   - Once the code is ready and you&#x27;ve saved the project, it will automatically be live with a public URL. This URL will act as your skill&#x27;s endpoint.\n   - You can find this URL by clicking on &quot;Share&quot; and copying the live app URL. It will look something like `https://&lt;project-name&gt;.glitch.me`.\n\n6. **Set Up Your Alexa Developer Console**:\n   - Go to the [Alexa Developer Console](https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask).\n   - Create a new skill or edit your existing one.\n   - Under **Endpoint**, provide the public URL from Glitch.\n   - Make sure you select **HTTPS** for the endpoint and check that it\u2019s properly secured (Glitch URLs are HTTPS by default).\n\n7. **Test the Skill**:\n   - Use the Alexa Developer Console\u2019s built-in tools or your own Alexa device to test the skill.\n   - Make sure that when you ask Alexa a question, it hits your Glitch endpoint, sends a request to OpenAI\u2019s API, and reads the response back to you.\n\n### Final Considerations\n- **Debugging**: If things aren\u2019t working as expected, use the **Alexa Developer Console logs** and **Glitch\u2019s logs** (available under the \u201cLogs\u201d tab on the Glitch project) to troubleshoot.\n- **Enhancing**: Once the core functionality works, you can enhance it by adding more complex responses, email integration, or even monetizing the skill via Alexa\u2019s developer tools.\n\nThis approach allows you to avoid AWS entirely, while still developing a custom Alexa skill that integrates with ChatGPT.
