Now, follow these steps to integrate your Alexa skill with OpenAI&#x27;s ChatGPT using the Glitch platform:\n\n1. **Set up your project files**:\n   - Click on the `server.js` file on the left to open it.\n   - In this file, you&#x27;ll be writing the code that connects your Alexa skill with the OpenAI API.\n   - You can copy the template from GitHub that connects to OpenAI\u2019s ChatGPT, like the one you found earlier.\n\n2. **Modify your `package.json`**:\n   - Open the `package.json` file.\n   - Add the dependencies required for OpenAI API and Alexa, like `ask-sdk-core`, `ask-sdk-model`, and `axios`. Here\u2019s an example:\n     ```json\n     {\n       &quot;name&quot;: &quot;alexa-chatgpt&quot;,\n       &quot;version&quot;: &quot;1.0.0&quot;,\n       &quot;description&quot;: &quot;Alexa skill with ChatGPT integration&quot;,\n       &quot;dependencies&quot;: {\n         &quot;ask-sdk-core&quot;: &quot;^2.10.0&quot;,\n         &quot;ask-sdk-model&quot;: &quot;^1.25.0&quot;,\n         &quot;axios&quot;: &quot;^0.21.1&quot;\n       },\n       &quot;engines&quot;: {\n         &quot;node&quot;: &quot;14.x&quot;\n       }\n     }\n     ```\n\n3. **Write server-side logic**:\n   - In `server.js`, use the OpenAI and Alexa SDKs to create your logic.\n   - An example of server code to handle Alexa intents and route them to OpenAI API might look like this:\n     ```javascript\n     const Alexa = require(&#x27;ask-sdk-core&#x27;);\n     const axios = require(&#x27;axios&#x27;);\n\n     const getOpenAIResponse = async (userQuery) =&gt; {\n       const response = await axios.post(&#x27;https://api.openai.com/v1/engines/davinci-codex/completions&#x27;, {\n         prompt: userQuery,\n         max_tokens: 150\n       }, {\n         headers: {\n           &#x27;Authorization&#x27;: `Bearer YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY`\n         }\n       });\n       return response.data.choices[0].text;\n     };\n\n     const LaunchRequestHandler = {\n       canHandle(handlerInput) {\n         return Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &#x27;LaunchRequest&#x27;;\n       },\n       async handle(handlerInput) {\n         const speakOutput = &#x27;Welcome to your ChatGPT Alexa skill!&#x27;;\n         return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n           .speak(speakOutput)\n           .getResponse();\n       }\n     };\n\n     const OpenAIIntentHandler = {\n       canHandle(handlerInput) {\n         return Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &#x27;IntentRequest&#x27;\n           &amp;&amp; Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &#x27;GetAIResponseIntent&#x27;;\n       },\n       async handle(handlerInput) {\n         const query = handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request.intent.slots.query.value;\n         const response = await getOpenAIResponse(query);\n         return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n           .speak(response)\n           .getResponse();\n       }\n     };\n\n     const skillBuilder = Alexa.SkillBuilders.custom();\n\n     exports.handler = skillBuilder\n       .addRequestHandlers(\n         LaunchRequestHandler,\n         OpenAIIntentHandler\n       )\n       .lambda();\n     ```\n\n4. **Set your OpenAI API key**:\n   - In the `.env` file, store your OpenAI API key:\n     ```\n     OPENAI_API_KEY=your-openai-api-key-here\n     ```\n\n5. **Run your project**:\n   - Once the code is written, you can test it directly on Glitch.\n   - Click on `Tools` at the bottom and select `Logs` to see how the app behaves and if any errors pop up.\n\n6. **Connect with Alexa**:\n   - You can now use Glitch&#x27;s public URL (found in the `Share` button) as the backend for your Alexa skill by adding this URL in the endpoint section when configuring your Alexa skill in the Amazon Developer Console.\n\nLet me know how it goes or if you have any questions!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

&amp;&amp;\r\n      Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;AskToGPTIntent&quot;\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  async handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const question = Alexa.getSlotValue(\r\n      handlerInput.requestEnvelope,\r\n      &quot;question&quot;\r\n    );\r\n\r\n    const responseFromGPT = await askToGPT(question);\r\n\r\n    const formattedResponse = formatString(responseFromGPT);\r\n\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.speak(formattedResponse).getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst HelpIntentHandler = {\r\n  canHandle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return (\r\n      Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;IntentRequest&quot; &amp;&amp;\r\n      Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;AMAZON.HelpIntent&quot;\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const speakOutput =\r\n      &quot;Voc\u00ea pode perguntar algo como &#x27;chat, ideia de nome para beb\u00eas&#x27;&quot;;\r\n\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.speak(speakOutput).getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst CancelAndStopIntentHandler = {\r\n  canHandle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return (\r\n      Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;IntentRequest&quot; &amp;&amp;\r\n      (Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) ===\r\n        &quot;AMAZON.CancelIntent&quot; ||\r\n        Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) ===\r\n          &quot;AMAZON.StopIntent&quot;)\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const speakOutput = &quot;At\u00e9 mais!&quot;;\r\n\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.speak(speakOutput).getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst FallbackIntentHandler = {\r\n  canHandle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return (\r\n      Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;IntentRequest&quot; &amp;&amp;\r\n      Alexa.getIntentName(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) ===\r\n        &quot;AMAZON.FallbackIntent&quot;\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const speakOutput =\r\n      &quot;Desculpe, n\u00e3o tenho conhecimento sobre isso. Por favor, tente novamente.&quot;;\r\n\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.speak(speakOutput).getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst SessionEndedRequestHandler = {\r\n  canHandle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return (\r\n      Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) ===\r\n      &quot;SessionEndedRequest&quot;\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst IntentReflectorHandler = {\r\n  canHandle(handlerInput) {\r\n    return (\r\n      Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &quot;IntentRequest&quot;\r\n    );\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const speakOutput = `Que tal me perguntar algo como &#x27;quanto est\u00e1 o d\u00f3lar hoje?&#x27;`;\r\n\r\n    return handlerInput.responseBuilder.speak(speakOutput).getResponse();\r\n  },\r\n};\r\n\r\nconst ErrorHandler = {\r\n  canHandle() {\r\n    return true;\r\n  },\r\n  handle(handlerInput) {\r\n    const speakOutput =\r\n      &quot;Desculpe, parece que tivemos um problema aqui! The code currently uses the ES module syntax (`import axios from &quot;axios&quot;`), but your environment is likely set up to use CommonJS, which uses `require()` instead. Glitch by default runs on Node.js using CommonJS, so you&#x27;ll need to adjust the way Axios is imported.\n\nTo fix the issue, replace the `import axios from &quot;axios&quot;;` line with:\n\n```javascript\nconst axios = require(&quot;axios&quot;);\n```\n\nYou can then re-save your `index.js` file, and the code should work in your current setup. Here&#x27;s a step-by-step guide on how to simulate requests and test your skill:\n\n### Steps to Simulate an Alexa Request:\n\n1. **Sign In to the Alexa Developer Console**:\n   - Go to the [Alexa Developer Console](https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask).\n   - Sign in with your Amazon account.\n\n2. **Select Your Skill**:\n   - Once you are logged in, navigate to the **Skills** tab in the console.\n   - Select the skill you want to test (which should be the one you&#x27;re developing with the Alexa-GPT integration).\n\n3. **Navigate to the Test Tab**:\n   - In the skill dashboard, click on the **Test** tab at the top.\n   - Ensure that the skill is in **Development** mode. You can switch to **Development** by toggling the switch to **Enabled**.\n\n4. **Enter Utterances**:\n   - In the **Test** tab, under **Alexa Simulator**, you can simulate user requests.\n   - In the text box where it says &quot;Enter Utterance,&quot; type in the request you want to test (e.g., &quot;Ask GPT, what is the capital of France?&quot;).\n   - You can also test your invocation name (e.g., &quot;Open [Your Skill Name]&quot;) to start the skill.\n\n5. **Monitor the Responses**:\n   - After typing your utterance, Alexa will simulate the response. You\u2019ll see both the text and voice response Alexa would give.\n   - If your skill makes an external API request (such as to GPT-4 via OpenAI), ensure that it is working correctly and returning the expected output.\n\n6. **Test with Voice**:\n   - You can also simulate voice input by clicking the **Microphone** button and speaking the utterance you want to test.\n\n7. **View JSON Input and Output**:\n   - If you want to see the detailed request/response interaction, scroll down to view the **JSON Input** (what Alexa sends to your skill) and **JSON Output** (what your skill returns to Alexa). This can help in debugging or verifying the data flow.\n\n8. **Review Logs** (Optional):\n   - If you&#x27;re using Glitch or another hosting platform, check the logs in your Glitch project for any errors or issues when handling the requests.\n\nOnce the skill works as expected in the Alexa Developer Console, you can also test it on your Alexa-enabled devices if the skill is enabled for your account.\n\nLet me know if you encounter any issues while testing!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here&#x27;s how you can do it:\n\n### Steps to Simulate Alexa Request via Postman:\n1. **Install Postman**: If you don&#x27;t have it installed, download it from [here](https://www.postman.com/downloads/).\n   \n2. **Create a New Request**:\n   - Open Postman and click on `New` to create a new HTTP request.\n   - Choose **POST** as the HTTP method.\n\n3. **Set the URL**:  \n   Set the Glitch project URL followed by `/`. For example:  \n   ```\n   https://magic-bramble-lobe.glitch.me/\n   ```\n\n4. **Set Headers**:\n   Add these headers:\n   - `Content-Type: application/json`\n\n5. **Set the Body**:\n   - In Postman, select the `Body` tab.\n   - Choose `raw` and set it to `JSON`.\n   - Copy this JSON example to simulate a simple Alexa intent request:\n     ```json\n     {\n       &quot;version&quot;: &quot;1.0&quot;,\n       &quot;session&quot;: {\n         &quot;new&quot;: true,\n         &quot;sessionId&quot;: &quot;amzn1.echo-api.session.test&quot;,\n         &quot;application&quot;: {\n           &quot;applicationId&quot;: &quot;amzn1.ask.skill.test&quot;\n         },\n         &quot;user&quot;: {\n           &quot;userId&quot;: &quot;amzn1.ask.account.testUser&quot;\n         }\n       },\n       &quot;context&quot;: {\n         &quot;System&quot;: {\n           &quot;application&quot;: {\n             &quot;applicationId&quot;: &quot;amzn1.ask.skill.test&quot;\n           },\n           &quot;user&quot;: {\n             &quot;userId&quot;: &quot;amzn1.ask.account.testUser&quot;\n           }\n         }\n       },\n       &quot;request&quot;: {\n         &quot;type&quot;: &quot;IntentRequest&quot;,\n         &quot;intent&quot;: {\n           &quot;name&quot;: &quot;AskToGPTIntent&quot;,\n           &quot;slots&quot;: {\n             &quot;question&quot;: {\n               &quot;name&quot;: &quot;question&quot;,\n               &quot;value&quot;: &quot;What is the capital of France?&quot;\n             }\n           }\n         }\n       }\n     }\n     ```\n\n6. **Send the Request**:\n   - Press `Send` and check the response from your Glitch project.\n\nIf everything is configured correctly, you should get a response from your skill, simulating how Alexa would respond.\n\nLet me know if this works or if you run into any issues!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here&#x27;s how you can do it:\n\n### Steps to Upload Code to Developer Console:\n\n1. **Open the Amazon Developer Console**:\n   - Log in to your [Amazon Developer Console](https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask).\n\n2. **Create a New Alexa Skill**:\n   - In the console, click **Create Skill**.\n   - Name your skill, choose the default language, and select the **Custom** model.\n\n3. **Choose a Method for Hosting the Skill**:\n   - When asked about backend services, choose **Provision Your Own**.\n   - This allows you to upload your code manually via an AWS Lambda function or a custom endpoint.\n\n4. **Set Up an AWS Lambda Function (Optional)**:\n   - You can upload your skill to AWS Lambda if you want it to be hosted in the cloud.\n   - Set up a Lambda function in AWS, and you can paste the Node.js code there.\n   - Once done, copy the **Lambda ARN** and paste it into the Alexa Developer Console in the **Endpoint** section of your skill.\n\n5. **Upload Your Code**:\n   - Go to the **Code** section of your skill in the Developer Console.\n   - Here you can directly upload or link to the backend code. Since you\u2019ve been working in Node.js on Glitch, you can copy and paste that code into the appropriate place.\n\n6. **Add Your API Key**:\n   - Make sure your `.env` file or environment variables are set properly.\n   - Add your OpenAI API key and any other configurations to the Lambda function or server endpoint.\n\n7. **Test Your Skill**:\n   - In the **Test** section of the Developer Console, enable testing for your skill and simulate requests.\n   - You can input the text or voice commands you want Alexa to process.\n\n8. **Deploy the Skill**:\n   - Once testing works, you can submit the skill for certification to make it publicly available.\n\n### Potential Issues:\n- **Long Response Time**: If your code takes more than 30 seconds to respond, as in the case of cloud timeout errors on Glitch, you may need to optimize or paginate the API requests to ensure Alexa doesn&#x27;t time out.\n- **Function Timeouts**: AWS Lambda functions have a default timeout of 3 seconds, but this can be extended up to 15 minutes (make sure to increase the timeout in the Lambda configuration if necessary).\n\nBy following these steps, you can move your Glitch-hosted code to the official Alexa platform, test it, and deploy it as a fully functional skill."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here are steps you can take to verify your code:\n\n### 1. **Test API Calls Locally (Postman)**:\n   - Use **Postman** or a similar tool to send requests to your OpenAI API with the same format your Alexa skill would use.\n   - Check for proper responses from the GPT-4 API. This ensures that the API integration works before involving Alexa.\n\n### 2. **Local Simulation via Node.js**:\n   - Run your code locally by simulating a request.\n   - Make sure you have Node.js installed on your machine.\n   - You can run your `index.js` locally with commands like `node index.js` to see if it throws any errors or returns the expected responses.\n\n### 3. **Using the Alexa Simulator**:\n   - In the **Alexa Developer Console**, you can create a bare-bones version of your skill without fully deploying it.\n   - Use the **Alexa Simulator** to test the voice interactions and see how the backend responds.\n   - You don\u2019t need to submit the skill for certification to test it.\n\n### 4. **Check Logs on Glitch or Lambda**:\n   - Ensure your code is free of errors by checking the logs in Glitch or AWS Lambda after running it.\n   - Glitch shows logs in the console, and Lambda logs are available via **CloudWatch**.\n   - This will help identify any runtime issues, such as missing environment variables or errors with axios requests.\n\n### 5. **Breakpoints/Debugging**:\n   - Use `console.log` statements to track where the request might be failing.\n   - For example, log the response from the GPT-4 API before sending it back to Alexa to ensure you\u2019re getting the expected output.\n\n### 6. **Time Out Issues**:\n   - If requests are taking longer than expected (like what happened in Postman), try to reduce the `max_tokens` in your OpenAI API call or optimize how you handle API responses.\n   - If the issue persists, it could be an issue with the environment (e.g., Glitch limitations), in which case deploying to Lambda might be better for response times.\n\nIf your code passes these tests without significant issues, it\u2019s more likely that it will work properly when moved to the Alexa Developer Console."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/blogs/alexa/alexa-skills-kit/2023/09/alexa-llm-fall-devices-services-sep-2023", "domain": "developer.amazon.com", "text": "\n[Image 5: Alexa Orchestration] \n\nConnect your APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM\n\nTo integrate APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM, you will provide: 1) your API endpoints and definitions 2) natural language annotations and descriptions of your APIs and business logic and 3) CX examples for when to call the APIs. This new integration model allows you to build experiences that enable customers\u00a0to participate in multi-turn, cross-skill conversations. For example, a customer planning a trip might ask about the best time of year to visit, places to see, and hotel reservations in the same conversation. To fulfill this task, relevant APIs will be called based on the API definitions and descriptions provided by you. As Alexa orchestrates and chains together intermediate natural language reasoning steps, it decomposes complex tasks into smaller, more manageable steps, and constructs the response to the customer. Alexa is able to complete these complex tasks in real time in line with customer expectations for voice interactions.\n\nWe have also enhanced our Skill manifest with an increased number of configuration fields to build LLM-based experiences.\u00a0\n\nmodelFacingName\u00a0and\u00a0modelFacingDescription\u00a0fields are used by the model to understand the functionality the Alexa Skill provides.\u00a0actionProvider\u00a0enables a new type of integration for integrating APIs with Alexa.\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n        &quot;manifest&quot;: {\n            &quot;modelFacingName&quot;: &quot;Restaurant Reservations&quot;,\n            &quot;modelFacingDescription&quot;: &quot;Use this to book restaurant reservations&quot;,\n            &quot;publishingInformation&quot;: {\n              // same as before\n            },\n            &quot;apis&quot;: {\n                &quot;actionProvider&quot;: {\n                    &quot;endpoint&quot;: { \n                        &quot;uri&quot;: &quot;arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:452493640596:function:restaurantReservationsHandler&quot;\n                    }\n                }\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\nTo make it simpler for developers to author and maintain API specifications and logic, we will support API declarations using our SDKs for the most common interface languages, starting with TypeScript.\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    @Service\n    export class RestaurantReservationService {\n      @Description(&quot;Use this method to find restaurants by the zipCode&quot;)\n      public findRestaurants(zipCode: string) : Promise&lt;Restaurant&gt; {\n        // restaurant search logic\n      }\n\n      @Description(&quot;Use this to reserve a restaurant, confirm with the user before reserving&quot;)\n      public reserveRestaurant(restaurant: Restaurant, partySize: number, date: string): Promise&lt;string&gt; {\n        // reservation logic \n      }\n    }\n\n    @Description(&quot;Restaurant schema&quot;)\n    export interface Restaurant {\n        restaurantId: string;\n        name: string;\n        address: string;\n        address2: string;\n        city: string;\n        state: string;\n        country: string;\n    }\n\nConnect your content with Alexa\u2019s LLM\u00a0\n\nYou will also be able to build content-driven, ambient experiences and deliver them to over half a billion Alexa-enabled devices. You can use unstructured data like product manuals or websites, or structured data from existing databases to enable customers to find the perfect show on Prime Video, get summaries of earnings reports, access recipes from an expert chef and more. These experiences will be powered by techniques such as retrieval augmented generation without needing to train core LLM models on your data.\u00a0  \n\nTo integrate content, create a content spec that includes 1) a short natural language description of the content (e.g., FAQs on amenities and guest services) 2) instructions on the desired use-cases to support and 3) the unstructured content or structured data, and ingest them using our new tools. These tools include managed instances of vector databases, which eliminate the need for you to provision and maintain your own services. When a customer asks for information related to your content, Alexa searches the content store, and forms a response using the most relevant information.\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n        &quot;manifest&quot;: {\n            &quot;modelFacingName&quot;: &quot;Food Recipes&quot;,\n            &quot;modelFacingDescription&quot;: &quot;Use this to find food recipes.&quot;,\n            &quot;publishingInformation&quot;: {\n              // same as before\n            },\n            &quot;apis&quot;: {\n                &quot;contentProvider&quot;: {\n                    &quot;sources&quot;: [\n                        {\n                            &quot;location&quot;: &quot;skillpackage://content/food-recipes.pdf&quot;\n                        }\n                    ]\n                }\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\nConnect your own LLM with Alexa devices and experiences\n\nIn addition, we understand that you may have already purpose-built your own LLMs or leveraged LLMs offered through services like Amazon Bedrock. When you want to bring your LLM-based experiences to life through expressive voice or ambient visuals, and distribute them to Alexa\u2019s devices, you will have the ability to integrate your Alexa Skill with one or more LLMs of your choice with a new tool. To integrate third-party LLMs, all you\u2019ll have to do is integrate with automatic speech recognition (ASR) or utterance text using a simple SDK that supports the entire range of multimodal experiences enabled by Alexa.\u00a0  \n\nWe\u2019re excited about the experiences being created by developers, and we\u2019ll have more to share soon from companies like Character.AI, Splash, BMW, Volley, Sleep Jar, Voice Apps, and OpenTable who are enabling customers to do things like talk to fictional characters, create their own songs, play\u00a0single and multi-agent driven games on Alexa-enabled devices, learn about the features of their vehicle and so much more.\u00a0  \n\nLeverage differentiated offerings for smart home developers  \n\nToday, customers have connected over 400 million smart home devices to Alexa. Our partners have been critical in helping build smart home experiences\u00a0with devices from all brands working seamlessly together to make customers\u2019 lives easier. We will be leveraging generative AI to allow customers to control their smart home devices for a variety of actions through flexible and natural conversations, which Alexa\u2019s LLM will map to the unique and differentiated features of their products. To cover the broadest set of use cases, we will be providing developers with a path for both common integrations such as on/off or start/stop actions, and more complex ones such as actions related to dynamic lighting or custom cleaning operations for a vacuum cleaner.  \n\nSmart home Generic Controller Interfaces such as our existing Alexa.RangeController and Alexa.ModeController remain a simple yet effective way to integrate devices with Alexa for common use cases. A new interface called Action Controller extends this further by enabling device makers to model simple actions, targets, and states to control their devices, giving customers the ability to interact naturally with their devices. This means customers using Alexa\u2019s LLM can say \u201cAlexa, the floor is dirty,\u201d and Alexa will be able to infer the intended action is \u2018vacuum\u2019, and state \u2018start.\u2019 Action Controller makes it simple for device makers to model new supported actions and targets. To take advantage of Action Controller, you need to 1) define your supported device actions such as clean, mop, or dock 2) define a list of targets such as \u2018kitchen\u2019 or \u2018living room,\u2019 3) choose the state(s) to support (choose one or more actions from start/stop/pause/resume) and 4) implement the required directive and state updates when Alexa sends the requested actions to your skills.\n\nBelow is an example of a multi-functional device modeled using the Action Controller instance. In this example, the device supports cleaning type actions (such as \u2018vacuum,\u2019) a list of target zones and device action states (start/stop/pause/resume.)\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    { &quot;capabilities&quot;: [{\n        &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AlexaInterface&quot;,\n        &quot;interface&quot;: &quot;Alexa.ActionController&quot;,\n        &quot;instance&quot;: &quot;Robot.Clean&quot;,\n        &quot;configuration&quot;: {\n            &quot;supportedActions&quot;: [{ //An identifier device maker defined for the actions reported.\n                &quot;id&quot;: &quot;Vacuum-device-maker-defined-identifier&quot;,\n                &quot;friendlyNames&quot;: [{\n                    &quot;@type&quot;: &quot;asset&quot;,\n                    &quot;value&quot;: {\n                      &quot;assetId&quot;: &quot;Alexa.Actions.Vacuum&quot;\n            }}]}],\n            &quot;supportedStates&quot;: [\n              &quot;START&quot;,\n              &quot;STOP&quot;,\n              &quot;PAUSE&quot;,\n              &quot;RESUME&quot;\n            ],\n            &quot;target&quot;: {\n              &quot;supportedTargets&quot;: [{ //A list of identifiers device maker defined for the targets reported\n                 &quot;id&quot;: &quot;space-id-1&quot;,\n                 &quot;friendlyNames&quot;: [\n                  {\n                    &quot;@type&quot;: &quot;asset&quot;,\n                    &quot;value&quot;: {\n                    &quot;assetId&quot;: &quot;Alexa.Space.Kitchen&quot;\n    }}]}]}}}]}\n\nBelow is the example of the directive a device maker will receive for the start action:\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n      &quot;directive&quot;: {\n      &quot;header&quot;: {\n      &quot;namespace&quot;: &quot;Alexa.ActionController&quot;,\n      &quot;instance&quot;: &quot;Robot.Clean&quot;,\n      &quot;name&quot;: &quot;PerformAction&quot;,\n      &quot;messageId&quot;: &quot;message id&quot;,\n      }\n      &quot;payload&quot;: {\n      &quot;actionId&quot;: &quot;Vacuum-device-maker-defined-identifier&quot;,\n      &quot;targetIds&quot;: [&quot;&lt;the target identifier&gt;&quot;],\n      &quot;state&quot;: &quot;START&quot;\n      }}}\n\nFor device control beyond a simple action, more complex device states, or parameters, we are introducing Dynamic Controller, a new tool allowing developers to define a custom interface. Dynamic Controller enables customers to use a wider range of utterances to control the unique features of their smart home devices in a more conversational way (e.g. a customer can request a lighting solution provider to \u201cmake the lights like a misty forest\u201d \u2013 in the past they would only have been able to select from a list of predefined options). Dynamic Controller makes it simpler for smart home dev", "title": "Amazon announces LLM-powered tools for developers at the Devices and Services Fall Launch Event", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Amazon announces LLM-powered tools for developers at the Devices and Services Fall Launch Event", "url": "https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/blogs/alexa/alexa-skills-kit/2023/09/alexa-llm-fall-devices-services-sep-2023", "text": "\n[Image 5: Alexa Orchestration] \n\nConnect your APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM\n\nTo integrate APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM, you will provide: 1) your API endpoints and definitions 2) natural language annotations and descriptions of your APIs and business logic and 3) CX examples for when to call the APIs. This new integration model allows you to build experiences that enable customers\u00a0to participate in multi-turn, cross-skill conversations. For example, a customer planning a trip might ask about the best time of year to visit, places to see, and hotel reservations in the same conversation. To fulfill this task, relevant APIs will be called based on the API definitions and descriptions provided by you. As Alexa orchestrates and chains together intermediate natural language reasoning steps, it decomposes complex tasks into smaller, more manageable steps, and constructs the response to the customer. Alexa is able to complete these complex tasks in real time in line with customer expectations for voice interactions.\n\nWe have also enhanced our Skill manifest with an increased number of configuration fields to build LLM-based experiences.\u00a0\n\nmodelFacingName\u00a0and\u00a0modelFacingDescription\u00a0fields are used by the model to understand the functionality the Alexa Skill provides.\u00a0actionProvider\u00a0enables a new type of integration for integrating APIs with Alexa.\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n        &quot;manifest&quot;: {\n            &quot;modelFacingName&quot;: &quot;Restaurant Reservations&quot;,\n            &quot;modelFacingDescription&quot;: &quot;Use this to book restaurant reservations&quot;,\n            &quot;publishingInformation&quot;: {\n              // same as before\n            },\n            &quot;apis&quot;: {\n                &quot;actionProvider&quot;: {\n                    &quot;endpoint&quot;: { \n                        &quot;uri&quot;: &quot;arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:452493640596:function:restaurantReservationsHandler&quot;\n                    }\n                }\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\nTo make it simpler for developers to author and maintain API specifications and logic, we will support API declarations using our SDKs for the most common interface languages, starting with TypeScript.\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    @Service\n    export class RestaurantReservationService {\n      @Description(&quot;Use this method to find restaurants by the zipCode&quot;)\n      public findRestaurants(zipCode: string) : Promise&lt;Restaurant&gt; {\n        // restaurant search logic\n      }\n\n      @Description(&quot;Use this to reserve a restaurant, confirm with the user before reserving&quot;)\n      public reserveRestaurant(restaurant: Restaurant, partySize: number, date: string): Promise&lt;string&gt; {\n        // reservation logic \n      }\n    }\n\n    @Description(&quot;Restaurant schema&quot;)\n    export interface Restaurant {\n        restaurantId: string;\n        name: string;\n        address: string;\n        address2: string;\n        city: string;\n        state: string;\n        country: string;\n    }\n\nConnect your content with Alexa\u2019s LLM\u00a0\n\nYou will also be able to build content-driven, ambient experiences and deliver them to over half a billion Alexa-enabled devices. You can use unstructured data like product manuals or websites, or structured data from existing databases to enable customers to find the perfect show on Prime Video, get summaries of earnings reports, access recipes from an expert chef and more. These experiences will be powered by techniques such as retrieval augmented generation without needing to train core LLM models on your data.\u00a0  \n\nTo integrate content, create a content spec that includes 1) a short natural language description of the content (e.g., FAQs on amenities and guest services) 2) instructions on the desired use-cases to support and 3) the unstructured content or structured data, and ingest them using our new tools. These tools include managed instances of vector databases, which eliminate the need for you to provision and maintain your own services. When a customer asks for information related to your content, Alexa searches the content store, and forms a response using the most relevant information.\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n        &quot;manifest&quot;: {\n            &quot;modelFacingName&quot;: &quot;Food Recipes&quot;,\n            &quot;modelFacingDescription&quot;: &quot;Use this to find food recipes.&quot;,\n            &quot;publishingInformation&quot;: {\n              // same as before\n            },\n            &quot;apis&quot;: {\n                &quot;contentProvider&quot;: {\n                    &quot;sources&quot;: [\n                        {\n                            &quot;location&quot;: &quot;skillpackage://content/food-recipes.pdf&quot;\n                        }\n                    ]\n                }\n            }\n        }\n    }\n\nConnect your own LLM with Alexa devices and experiences\n\nIn addition, we understand that you may have already purpose-built your own LLMs or leveraged LLMs offered through services like Amazon Bedrock. When you want to bring your LLM-based experiences to life through expressive voice or ambient visuals, and distribute them to Alexa\u2019s devices, you will have the ability to integrate your Alexa Skill with one or more LLMs of your choice with a new tool. To integrate third-party LLMs, all you\u2019ll have to do is integrate with automatic speech recognition (ASR) or utterance text using a simple SDK that supports the entire range of multimodal experiences enabled by Alexa.\u00a0  \n\nWe\u2019re excited about the experiences being created by developers, and we\u2019ll have more to share soon from companies like Character.AI, Splash, BMW, Volley, Sleep Jar, Voice Apps, and OpenTable who are enabling customers to do things like talk to fictional characters, create their own songs, play\u00a0single and multi-agent driven games on Alexa-enabled devices, learn about the features of their vehicle and so much more.\u00a0  \n\nLeverage differentiated offerings for smart home developers  \n\nToday, customers have connected over 400 million smart home devices to Alexa. Our partners have been critical in helping build smart home experiences\u00a0with devices from all brands working seamlessly together to make customers\u2019 lives easier. We will be leveraging generative AI to allow customers to control their smart home devices for a variety of actions through flexible and natural conversations, which Alexa\u2019s LLM will map to the unique and differentiated features of their products. To cover the broadest set of use cases, we will be providing developers with a path for both common integrations such as on/off or start/stop actions, and more complex ones such as actions related to dynamic lighting or custom cleaning operations for a vacuum cleaner.  \n\nSmart home Generic Controller Interfaces such as our existing Alexa.RangeController and Alexa.ModeController remain a simple yet effective way to integrate devices with Alexa for common use cases. A new interface called Action Controller extends this further by enabling device makers to model simple actions, targets, and states to control their devices, giving customers the ability to interact naturally with their devices. This means customers using Alexa\u2019s LLM can say \u201cAlexa, the floor is dirty,\u201d and Alexa will be able to infer the intended action is \u2018vacuum\u2019, and state \u2018start.\u2019 Action Controller makes it simple for device makers to model new supported actions and targets. To take advantage of Action Controller, you need to 1) define your supported device actions such as clean, mop, or dock 2) define a list of targets such as \u2018kitchen\u2019 or \u2018living room,\u2019 3) choose the state(s) to support (choose one or more actions from start/stop/pause/resume) and 4) implement the required directive and state updates when Alexa sends the requested actions to your skills.\n\nBelow is an example of a multi-functional device modeled using the Action Controller instance. In this example, the device supports cleaning type actions (such as \u2018vacuum,\u2019) a list of target zones and device action states (start/stop/pause/resume.)\u00a0\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    { &quot;capabilities&quot;: [{\n        &quot;type&quot;: &quot;AlexaInterface&quot;,\n        &quot;interface&quot;: &quot;Alexa.ActionController&quot;,\n        &quot;instance&quot;: &quot;Robot.Clean&quot;,\n        &quot;configuration&quot;: {\n            &quot;supportedActions&quot;: [{ //An identifier device maker defined for the actions reported.\n                &quot;id&quot;: &quot;Vacuum-device-maker-defined-identifier&quot;,\n                &quot;friendlyNames&quot;: [{\n                    &quot;@type&quot;: &quot;asset&quot;,\n                    &quot;value&quot;: {\n                      &quot;assetId&quot;: &quot;Alexa.Actions.Vacuum&quot;\n            }}]}],\n            &quot;supportedStates&quot;: [\n              &quot;START&quot;,\n              &quot;STOP&quot;,\n              &quot;PAUSE&quot;,\n              &quot;RESUME&quot;\n            ],\n            &quot;target&quot;: {\n              &quot;supportedTargets&quot;: [{ //A list of identifiers device maker defined for the targets reported\n                 &quot;id&quot;: &quot;space-id-1&quot;,\n                 &quot;friendlyNames&quot;: [\n                  {\n                    &quot;@type&quot;: &quot;asset&quot;,\n                    &quot;value&quot;: {\n                    &quot;assetId&quot;: &quot;Alexa.Space.Kitchen&quot;\n    }}]}]}}}]}\n\nBelow is the example of the directive a device maker will receive for the start action:\n\n\u2398Copy code Copied to clipboard\n\n    {\n      &quot;directive&quot;: {\n      &quot;header&quot;: {\n      &quot;namespace&quot;: &quot;Alexa.ActionController&quot;,\n      &quot;instance&quot;: &quot;Robot.Clean&quot;,\n      &quot;name&quot;: &quot;PerformAction&quot;,\n      &quot;messageId&quot;: &quot;message id&quot;,\n      }\n      &quot;payload&quot;: {\n      &quot;actionId&quot;: &quot;Vacuum-device-maker-defined-identifier&quot;,\n      &quot;targetIds&quot;: [&quot;&lt;the target identifier&gt;&quot;],\n      &quot;state&quot;: &quot;START&quot;\n      }}}\n\nFor device control beyond a simple action, more complex device states, or parameters, we are introducing Dynamic Controller, a new tool allowing developers to define a custom interface. Dynamic Controller enables customers to use a wider range of utterances to control the unique features of their smart home devices in a more conversational way (e.g. a customer can request a lighting solution provider to \u201cmake the lights like a misty forest\u201d \u2013 in the past they would only have been able to select from a list of predefined options). \u3011 \n\n# \n\nBuild LLM-powered Alexa experiences\n\n###### Explore tools that leverage our advances in generative AI.\n\n\u301065\u2020Learn more\u3011 \n\n# Create more natural, conversational and intuitive Alexa experiences\n\nDevelopers will be able to integrate their APIs or content into Alexa\u2019s LLM and create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more. In addition, smart home developers will be able to model actions easily to enable customers to interact naturally with their devices.\n\n#### Innovative and engaging\n\nBuild next generation customer experiences to help find dinner reservations, plan trips, control smart home devices and more.\n\n#### Flexibility and choice \n\nLeverage different LLM integration options to bring your innovations to customers around the world.  \n\n#### Simpler and faster\n\nBuild easily without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.\n\n### Featured\n\n###### \n\n[Image 0] \n\n- Jeff Bolton, CEO, Voice Apps\n\n[Image 1] \n\n- George Yianni, CTO, Philips Hue at Signify\n\n[Image 2] \n\n- Max Child, Co-Founder &amp; CEO, Volley\n\n[Image 3] \n\n- Richard Chang, Founder &amp; CEO, Roborock  \n\n[Image 4] \n\n- Nick Schwab, CEO, Sleep Jar\n\n[Image 5] \n\n- Shawn Stover, Vice President of SmartHome and Energy Solutions, GE Appliances\n\n[Image 6] \n\n- Chris Jones, CTO, iRobot\n\n[Image 7] \n\n- Kathy Sterio, President, GE Lighting, a Savant company\n\n[Image 8] \n\n- Albert Shan, Deputy GM, Xiaomi International\n\n[Image 9] \n\n##### Splash\n\nSplash harnesses generative AI to empower a new breed of musicians, creating songs by voice through the Splash experience on Alexa.\n\n[Image 10] \n\n##### Character.AI\n\nSee how Character.AI is creating the future of creativity and conversation by leveraging generative AI and Alexa.\n\n## Resources\n\n\u30105\u2020 Developer console \u3011 \n\n\u301065\u2020 Read the blog \u3011 \n\n\u301066\u2020 Watch the Keynote \u2020youtu.be\u3011 \n\n\u301067\u2020 Watch the Tech Talk \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nBack To Top \n\n### Alexa Skills Kit\n\n  * \u301068\u2020Alexa Skills Kit\u3011\n  * \u301069\u2020Get Started\u3011\n  * \u301070\u2020Get Deeper\u3011\n  * \u301071\u2020Grow Your Business\u3011\n  * \u301072\u2020What&#x27;s New\u3011\n\n### ASK Resources\n\n  * \u301048\u2020Tutorials &amp; \u301061\u2020 Device Makers \u3011 \n    * \u301062\u2020 Alexa Auto \u3011 \n    * \u301063\u2020 Alexa Science \u2020www.amazon.science\u3011 \n\n  * \u301064\u2020 Alexa Insider \u3011 \n\n# \n\nBuild LLM-powered Alexa experiences\n\n###### Explore tools that leverage our advances in generative AI.\n\n\u301065\u2020Learn more\u3011 \n\n# Create more natural, conversational and intuitive Alexa experiences\n\nDevelopers will be able to integrate their APIs or content into Alexa\u2019s LLM and create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more. In addition, smart home developers will be able to model actions easily to enable customers to interact naturally with their devices.\n\n#### Innovative and engaging\n\nBuild next generation customer experiences to help find dinner reservations, plan trips, control smart home devices and more.\n\n#### Flexibility and choice \n\nLeverage different LLM integration options to bring your innovations to customers around the world.  \n\n#### Simpler and faster\n\nBuild easily without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.\n\n### Featured\n\n###### \n\n[Image 0] \n\n- Jeff Bolton, CEO, Voice Apps\n\n[Image 1] \n\n- George Yianni, CTO, Philips Hue at Signify\n\n[Image 2] \n\n- Max Child, Co-Founder &amp; CEO, Volley\n\n[Image 3] \n\n- Richard Chang, Founder &amp; CEO, Roborock  \n\n[Image 4] \n\n- Nick Schwab, CEO, Sleep Jar\n\n[Image 5] \n\n- Shawn Stover, Vice President of SmartHome and Energy Solutions, GE Appliances\n\n[Image 6] \n\n- Chris Jones, CTO, iRobot\n\n[Image 7] \n\n- Kathy Sterio, President, GE Lighting, a Savant company\n\n[Image 8] \n\n- Albert Shan, Deputy GM, Xiaomi International\n\n[Image 9] \n\n##### Splash\n\nSplash harnesses generative AI to empower a new breed of musicians, creating songs by voice through the Splash experience on Alexa.\n\n[Image 10] \n\n##### Character.AI\n\nSee how Character.AI is creating the future of creativity and conversation by leveraging generative AI and Alexa.\n\n## Resources\n\n\u30105\u2020 Developer console \u3011 \n\n\u301065\u2020 Read the blog \u3011 \n\n\u301066\u2020 Watch the Keynote \u2020youtu.be\u3011 \n\n\u301067\u2020 Watch the Tech Talk \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\nBack To Top \n\n### Alexa Skills Kit\n\n  * \u301068\u2020Alexa Skills Kit\u3011\n  * \u301069\u2020Get Started\u3011\n  * \u301070\u2020Get Deeper\u3011\n  * \u301071\u2020Grow Your Business\u3011\n  * \u301072\u2020What&#x27;s New\u3011\n\n### ASK Resources\n\n  * \u301048\u2020Tutorials &amp; Makers \u3011 \n    * \u301063\u2020 Alexa Auto \u3011 \n    * \u301064\u2020 Alexa Science \u2020www.amazon.science\u3011 \n\n  * \u301065\u2020 Alexa Insider \u3011 \n\n# Amazon showcases new customer experiences powered by generative AI at CES 2024\n\n\u301066\u2020Arun Krishnan\u3011  Jan 09, 2024\n\nShare:  [Image 0]  [Image 1]  [Image 2] \u301067\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Amazon CES 2024\u3011 \u301069\u2020Alexa Skills\u3011\n\n[Image 3: Blog_Header_Post_Img] \n\nAt CES 2024, we are showcasing how the world&#x27;s leading brands are building with Amazon&#x27;s devices and services, and leveraging the latest innovations in artificial intelligence to build the next generation of ambient experiences.\u00a0 This article is part of a \u301068\u2020series\u3011 that showcases select brands on display at the \u301070\u2020Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011.\n\nAt CES 2024, Amazon showcased how developers are using the latest advancements in generative AI to build the next generation of ambient experiences for customers engaging with Alexa.  \n\nHaving passed half a billion Alexa-enabled devices sold, and with tens of millions of interactions every hour, Alexa has become part of the family in tens of millions of households. We\u2019ve always thought of Alexa as an evolving service, and we\u2019ve been continuously improving it since the day we introduced it in 2014.  \n\nVisitors to the Amazon Experience Area during CES 2024 will experience how Amazon\u2019s innovations in artificial intelligence helps people live productive and fulfilled lives by making every day better.\n\nThe \u301071\u2020Character.AI\u2020character.ai\u3011 Alexa experience brings to life the science-fiction dream of open-ended conversations and collaborations with computers. The experience allows customers to interact with any of predefined 28 Characters across four categories (General assistants, Skill helpers, Historical icons, and Just for fun).\n\nCustomers will also get access to even more ways for music to be created. Splash, an Alexa Fund portfolio company, is connecting its AI-powered music creation technology to Alexa, enabling customers to interact with the experience and do things like generate lyrics, select vocals and style, and make original music just by conversing with Alexa. From there, a link to the song is created in the experience that can be sent to the customer\u2019s mobile phone.\n\nVolley, also an Alexa Fund portfolio company, brings it\u2019s AI-powered \u201c20 Questions\u201d game to life. Volley\u2019s Alexa experience is a deeper version of the well known parlor game, using generative AI to interact with customers through questions and engaging conversation. All through the power of voice.\n\nThese experiences leverage our new LLM-powered tools announced at our Fall Devices and Services launch event. With these tools, developers will be able to create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more.  \n\nThe tools announced at the event will enable developers to integrate content and APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM to create conversational experiences for Alexa-enabled devices, or alternatively, integrate with an LLM of their choice without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.  \n\nYou can read more about the new developer tools at \u301072\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011. \u301070\u2020Visit the Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011 to see these experiences in action.\n\n#### Recommended Reading\n\n\u301073\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### &quot;A shared vision with Amazon to create unprecedented value for customers&quot;: Akira Toyoshima, CEO of Panasonic Entertainment &amp; Communication\n\n\u301074\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### Amazon announces expanded development options for device makers building connected devices with the Alexa Connect Kit for Matter\n\n\u301075\u2020 \u3011 \n\n# Amazon showcases new customer experiences powered by generative AI at CES 2024\n\n\u301066\u2020Arun Krishnan\u3011  Jan 09, 2024\n\nShare:  [Image 0]  [Image 1]  [Image 2] \u301067\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Amazon CES 2024\u3011 \u301069\u2020Alexa Skills\u3011\n\n[Image 3: Blog_Header_Post_Img] \n\nAt CES 2024, we are showcasing how the world&#x27;s leading brands are building with Amazon&#x27;s devices and services, and leveraging the latest innovations in artificial intelligence to build the next generation of ambient experiences.\u00a0 This article is part of a \u301068\u2020series\u3011 that showcases select brands on display at the \u301070\u2020Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011.\n\nAt CES 2024, Amazon showcased how developers are using the latest advancements in generative AI to build the next generation of ambient experiences for customers engaging with Alexa.  \n\nHaving passed half a billion Alexa-enabled devices sold, and with tens of millions of interactions every hour, Alexa has become part of the family in tens of millions of households. We\u2019ve always thought of Alexa as an evolving service, and we\u2019ve been continuously improving it since the day we introduced it in 2014.  \n\nVisitors to the Amazon Experience Area during CES 2024 will experience how Amazon\u2019s innovations in artificial intelligence helps people live productive and fulfilled lives by making every day better.\n\nThe \u301071\u2020Character.AI\u2020character.ai\u3011 Alexa experience brings to life the science-fiction dream of open-ended conversations and collaborations with computers. The experience allows customers to interact with any of predefined 28 Characters across four categories (General assistants, Skill helpers, Historical icons, and Just for fun).\n\nCustomers will also get access to even more ways for music to be created. Splash, an Alexa Fund portfolio company, is connecting its AI-powered music creation technology to Alexa, enabling customers to interact with the experience and do things like generate lyrics, select vocals and style, and make original music just by conversing with Alexa. From there, a link to the song is created in the experience that can be sent to the customer\u2019s mobile phone.\n\nVolley, also an Alexa Fund portfolio company, brings it\u2019s AI-powered \u201c20 Questions\u201d game to life. Volley\u2019s Alexa experience is a deeper version of the well known parlor game, using generative AI to interact with customers through questions and engaging conversation. All through the power of voice.\n\nThese experiences leverage our new LLM-powered tools announced at our Fall Devices and Services launch event. With these tools, developers will be able to create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more.  \n\nThe tools announced at the event will enable developers to integrate content and APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM to create conversational experiences for Alexa-enabled devices, or alternatively, integrate with an LLM of their choice without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.  \n\nYou can read more about the new developer tools at \u301072\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011. \u301070\u2020Visit the Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011 to see these experiences in action.\n\n#### "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1728944074.279042, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Based on what is available today, Amazon recently announced new tools that allow developers to integrate Large Language Models (LLMs) with Alexa, either through Amazon\u2019s own models or external ones. These tools were introduced during their 2023 fall devices and services event and are designed to make it easier for developers to bring their LLMs to Alexa-enabled devices. The key features include:\n\n1. **Integration with Alexa&#x27;s LLM**: Developers can create conversational experiences by integrating content and APIs into Alexa\u2019s built-in LLM, enabling real-time data access, voice interactions, and more.\n2. **Third-party LLM Support**: You can use an LLM of your choice (e.g., OpenAI&#x27;s GPT-4) with Alexa for various experiences, including generative AI-enhanced games or booking systems.\n3. **Simplified Development**: The new SDK makes it easier to develop for Alexa without complex code or specific interaction models, expanding the scope of what Alexa can do.\n\nThis means that with these updates, developers like you can build and integrate your own LLMs (such as GPT-4) into Alexa Skills and deploy them to users on Alexa-enabled devices.\n\nFor more detailed information on how to start using these new capabilities, you can visit Amazon\u2019s [Alexa AI Developer Page](https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/alexa/alexa-ai)\u3010238\u2020source\u3011\u3010239\u2020source\u3011."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

\u3011 \n\n# \n\nBuild LLM-powered Alexa experiences\n\n###### Explore tools that leverage our advances in generative AI.\n\n\u301065\u2020Learn more\u3011 \n\n# Create more natural, conversational and intuitive Alexa experiences\n\nDevelopers will be able to integrate their APIs or content into Alexa\u2019s LLM and create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more. In addition, smart home developers will be able to model actions easily to enable customers to interact naturally with their devices.\n\n#### Innovative and engaging\n\nBuild next generation customer experiences to help find dinner reservations, plan trips, control smart home devices and more.\n\n#### Flexibility and choice \n\nLeverage different LLM integration options to bring your innovations to customers around the world.  \n\n#### Simpler and faster\n\nBuild easily without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.\n\n### Featured\n\n###### \n\n[Image 0] \n\n- Jeff Bolton, CEO, Voice Apps\n\n[Image 1] \n\n- George Yianni, CTO, Philips Hue at Signify\n\n[Image 2] \n\n- Max Child, Co-Founder &amp; Connect Devices to Alexa Alexa Smart Home &amp; Alexa Gadgets\n\n      * \u301056\u2020 Smart Home Skills \u3011 \n      * \u301057\u2020 Echo Button Skills \u3011 \n      * \u301058\u2020 Alexa Gadgets Toolkit \u3011 \n\n    * \u301059\u2020 Manage Skills ASK CLI and SMAPI \u3011 \n\n  * \u301060\u2020 Blog \u3011 \n\n    * \u301061\u2020 Alexa Skills Kit \u3011 \n    * \u301062\u2020 Device Makers \u3011 \n    * \u301063\u2020 Alexa Auto \u3011 \n    * \u301064\u2020 Alexa Science \u2020www.amazon.science\u3011 \n\n  * \u301065\u2020 Alexa Insider \u3011 \n\n# Amazon showcases new customer experiences powered by generative AI at CES 2024\n\n\u301066\u2020Arun Krishnan\u3011  Jan 09, 2024\n\nShare:  [Image 0]  [Image 1]  [Image 2] \u301067\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Amazon CES 2024\u3011 \u301069\u2020Alexa Skills\u3011\n\n[Image 3: Blog_Header_Post_Img] \n\nAt CES 2024, we are showcasing how the world&#x27;s leading brands are building with Amazon&#x27;s devices and services, and leveraging the latest innovations in artificial intelligence to build the next generation of ambient experiences.\u00a0 This article is part of a \u301068\u2020series\u3011 that showcases select brands on display at the \u301070\u2020Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011.\n\nAt CES 2024, Amazon showcased how developers are using the latest advancements in generative AI to build the next generation of ambient experiences for customers engaging with Alexa.  \n\nHaving passed half a billion Alexa-enabled devices sold, and with tens of millions of interactions every hour, Alexa has become part of the family in tens of millions of households. We\u2019ve always thought of Alexa as an evolving service, and we\u2019ve been continuously improving it since the day we introduced it in 2014.  \n\nVisitors to the Amazon Experience Area during CES 2024 will experience how Amazon\u2019s innovations in artificial intelligence helps people live productive and fulfilled lives by making every day better.\n\nThe \u301071\u2020Character.AI\u2020character.ai\u3011 Alexa experience brings to life the science-fiction dream of open-ended conversations and collaborations with computers. The experience allows customers to interact with any of predefined 28 Characters across four categories (General assistants, Skill helpers, Historical icons, and Just for fun).\n\nCustomers will also get access to even more ways for music to be created. Splash, an Alexa Fund portfolio company, is connecting its AI-powered music creation technology to Alexa, enabling customers to interact with the experience and do things like generate lyrics, select vocals and style, and make original music just by conversing with Alexa. From there, a link to the song is created in the experience that can be sent to the customer\u2019s mobile phone.\n\nVolley, also an Alexa Fund portfolio company, brings it\u2019s AI-powered \u201c20 Questions\u201d game to life. Volley\u2019s Alexa experience is a deeper version of the well known parlor game, using generative AI to interact with customers through questions and engaging conversation. All through the power of voice.\n\nThese experiences leverage our new LLM-powered tools announced at our Fall Devices and Services launch event. With these tools, developers will be able to create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more.  \n\nThe tools announced at the event will enable developers to integrate content and APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM to create conversational experiences for Alexa-enabled devices, or alternatively, integrate with an LLM of their choice without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.  \n\nYou can read more about the new developer tools at \u301072\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011. \u301070\u2020Visit the Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011 to see these experiences in action.\n\n#### Recommended Reading\n\n\u301073\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### &quot;A shared vision with Amazon to create unprecedented value for customers&quot;: Akira Toyoshima, CEO of Panasonic Entertainment &amp; \u3011 \n\n# \n\nBuild LLM-powered Alexa experiences\n\n###### Explore tools that leverage our advances in generative AI.\n\n\u301065\u2020Learn more\u3011 \n\n# Create more natural, conversational and intuitive Alexa experiences\n\nDevelopers will be able to integrate their APIs or content into Alexa\u2019s LLM and create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more. In addition, smart home developers will be able to model actions easily to enable customers to interact naturally with their devices.\n\n#### Innovative and engaging\n\nBuild next generation customer experiences to help find dinner reservations, plan trips, control smart home devices and more.\n\n#### Flexibility and choice \n\nLeverage different LLM integration options to bring your innovations to customers around the world.  \n\n#### Simpler and faster\n\nBuild easily without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.\n\n### Featured\n\n###### \n\n[Image 0] \n\n- Jeff Bolton, CEO, Voice Apps\n\n[Image 1] \n\n- George Yianni, CTO, Philips Hue at Signify\n\n[Image 2] \n\n- Max Child, Co-Founder &amp; \u3011 \n\n# Amazon showcases new customer experiences powered by generative AI at CES 2024\n\n\u301066\u2020Arun Krishnan\u3011  Jan 09, 2024\n\nShare:  [Image 0]  [Image 1]  [Image 2] \u301067\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Amazon CES 2024\u3011 \u301069\u2020Alexa Skills\u3011\n\n[Image 3: Blog_Header_Post_Img] \n\nAt CES 2024, we are showcasing how the world&#x27;s leading brands are building with Amazon&#x27;s devices and services, and leveraging the latest innovations in artificial intelligence to build the next generation of ambient experiences.\u00a0 This article is part of a \u301068\u2020series\u3011 that showcases select brands on display at the \u301070\u2020Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011.\n\nAt CES 2024, Amazon showcased how developers are using the latest advancements in generative AI to build the next generation of ambient experiences for customers engaging with Alexa.  \n\nHaving passed half a billion Alexa-enabled devices sold, and with tens of millions of interactions every hour, Alexa has become part of the family in tens of millions of households. We\u2019ve always thought of Alexa as an evolving service, and we\u2019ve been continuously improving it since the day we introduced it in 2014.  \n\nVisitors to the Amazon Experience Area during CES 2024 will experience how Amazon\u2019s innovations in artificial intelligence helps people live productive and fulfilled lives by making every day better.\n\nThe \u301071\u2020Character.AI\u2020character.ai\u3011 Alexa experience brings to life the science-fiction dream of open-ended conversations and collaborations with computers. The experience allows customers to interact with any of predefined 28 Characters across four categories (General assistants, Skill helpers, Historical icons, and Just for fun).\n\nCustomers will also get access to even more ways for music to be created. Splash, an Alexa Fund portfolio company, is connecting its AI-powered music creation technology to Alexa, enabling customers to interact with the experience and do things like generate lyrics, select vocals and style, and make original music just by conversing with Alexa. From there, a link to the song is created in the experience that can be sent to the customer\u2019s mobile phone.\n\nVolley, also an Alexa Fund portfolio company, brings it\u2019s AI-powered \u201c20 Questions\u201d game to life. Volley\u2019s Alexa experience is a deeper version of the well known parlor game, using generative AI to interact with customers through questions and engaging conversation. All through the power of voice.\n\nThese experiences leverage our new LLM-powered tools announced at our Fall Devices and Services launch event. With these tools, developers will be able to create experiences that allow customers to access real-time data, enjoy immersive generative AI-enhanced games, perform tasks like booking restaurant reservations, getting a succinct summary of a trending news story, and more.  \n\nThe tools announced at the event will enable developers to integrate content and APIs with Alexa\u2019s LLM to create conversational experiences for Alexa-enabled devices, or alternatively, integrate with an LLM of their choice without having to write complex code or train specific interaction models.  \n\nYou can read more about the new developer tools at \u301072\u2020developer.amazon.com\u3011. \u301070\u2020Visit the Amazon Experience Area at CES 2024\u3011 to see these experiences in action.\n\n#### Recommended Reading\n\n\u301073\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### &quot;A shared vision with Amazon to create unprecedented value for customers&quot;: Akira Toyoshima, CEO of Panasonic Entertainment &amp; Communication\n\n\u301074\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### Amazon announces expanded development options for device makers building connected devices with the Alexa Connect Kit for Matter\n\n\u301075\u2020 \u3011 \n\n##### Amazon Alexa Fund portfolio company MultiOn aims to be a personal assistant for everyone\n\n#### Subscribe\n\nBack to Top \n\n### Alexa Skills Kit\n\n  * \u301076\u2020Alexa Skills Voice Service\n\n  * \u301085\u2020Alexa Voice Service\u3011\n  * \u301086\u2020Learn\u3011\n  * \u301087\u2020Design\u3011\n  * \u301088\u2020Build\u3011\n  * \u301089\u2020Launch\u3011\n\n### AVS Kennedy. The &quot;magic bullet&quot; refers to the single bullet that allegedly caused multiple wounds to both President Kennedy and Texas Governor John Connally. It has been a point of contention and debate for decades.\n\n**Applicability of Actuarial Statistics:**\n\nActuarial statistics are typically used to assess risk and predict future events by analyzing large datasets of similar occurrences\u2014such as life expectancies, insurance claims, or accident rates. These statistics rely on the law of large numbers to produce meaningful probabilities.\n\n**Challenges in Applying Actuarial Statistics to the &quot;Magic Bullet&quot;:**\n\n1. **Unique Event:** The assassination is a singular historical event with no directly comparable cases. This uniqueness makes it unsuitable for traditional actuarial analysis, which depends on patterns observed in numerous similar events.\n\n2. **Lack of Data:** There is insufficient empirical data on similar ballistic scenarios where one bullet caused multiple wounds in two people under the exact same conditions. Without a dataset, calculating a statistical probability is not feasible.\n\n3. **Complex Variables:** Factors such as bullet trajectory, the relative positions of Kennedy and Connally, bullet deformation, and human anatomy introduce complexities that are better addressed through forensic science than actuarial methods.\n\n**Forensic Analysis Over Statistical Probability:**\n\n- **Warren Commission Findings:** The Warren Commission conducted extensive forensic analyses, including reenactments and ballistic tests. They concluded that the single-bullet theory was plausible given the evidence.\n\n- **Subsequent Studies:** Later investigations, including those by the FBI and independent experts, have revisited the &quot;magic bullet&quot; scenario using advanced technology. Many have found that the bullet&#x27;s trajectory and the wounds are consistent with the laws of physics and ballistics.\n\n**Conclusion:**\n\nWhile the &quot;magic bullet&quot; theory raises valid questions, assigning a weighted statistical probability using actuarial methods is not practical due to the lack of comparable data and the event&#x27;s unique nature. The plausibility of the single-bullet theory is better evaluated through forensic science, which considers the physical evidence and applies principles of physics and biology.\n\n**Recommendation:**\n\nFor a deeper understanding of the &quot;magic bullet&quot; theory, I suggest reviewing forensic analyses and expert testimonies from reputable sources. Estimating the likelihood of a presidential assassination occurring during a public event, such as a parade, can be approached by analyzing historical data. While this method has limitations, it can provide some insight into the relative rarity of such events.\n\n### **Historical Data on Presidential Assassinations**\n\n**Successful Assassinations:**\n\n1. **Abraham Lincoln** (1865) \u2013 Assassinated by John Wilkes Booth at Ford&#x27;s Theatre.\n2. **James A. Garfield** (1881) \u2013 Shot by Charles J. Guiteau at a train station; died weeks later.\n3. **William McKinley** (1901) \u2013 Shot by Leon Czolgosz at the Pan-American Exposition; died days later.\n4. **John F. Kennedy** (1963) \u2013 Assassinated by Lee Harvey Oswald during a motorcade in Dallas, Texas.\n\n**Notable Assassination Attempts:**\n\n- **Theodore Roosevelt** (1912) \u2013 Shot during a speech while campaigning for a non-consecutive term; survived.\n- **Franklin D. Roosevelt** (1933) \u2013 An attempt was made shortly after his election; he was unharmed.\n- **Harry S. Truman** (1950) \u2013 An attempt at Blair House; he was unharmed.\n- **Gerald Ford** (1975) \u2013 Two separate attempts; both failed.\n- **Ronald Reagan** (1981) \u2013 Shot by John Hinckley Jr.; survived after surgery.\n\n### **Estimating the Likelihood**\n\n**Total Number of Presidents:** 46 (as of 2021)\n\n**Time Span:** 232 years (from 1789 to 2021)\n\n**Assassinations:**\n\n- **Successful:** 4\n- **Attempts (including successful):** Approximately 20 known attempts\n\n**Challenges in Calculation:**\n\n1. **Incomplete Data on Public Events:** Presidents have participated in countless public events, but precise records of every parade or appearance are not readily available.\n2. **Changing Frequency of Events:** The number of public appearances has varied with each presidency and over different historical periods.\n3. **Evolution of Security Measures:** Advances in security have significantly altered the risk over time.\n4. **Contextual Factors:** Political climate, societal tensions, and technological advancements influence the likelihood of an assassination attempt.\n\n**Simplified Calculation:**\n\nFor a rough estimate, let&#x27;s make some assumptions:\n\n1. **Average Number of Public Events per President per Year:** Suppose a president attends 200 public events annually (this is a hypothetical figure for illustrative purposes).\n2. **Total Number of Presidential Years:** 232 years\n3. **Total Public Events:** \\( 200 \\text{ events/year} \\times 232 \\text{ years} = 46,400 \\text{ events} \\)\n\n**Probability of a Successful Assassination per Event:**\n\n- \\( \\text{Probability} = \\frac{\\text{Number of Successful Assassinations}}{\\text{Total Public Events}} \\)\n- \\( \\text{Probability} = \\frac{4}{46,400} \\approx 0.0086\\% \\) chance per event\n\n**Probability of an Assassination Attempt per Event:**\n\n- \\( \\text{Probability} = \\frac{\\text{Number of Attempts}}{\\text{Total Public Events}} \\)\n- \\( \\text{Probability} = \\frac{20}{46,400} \\approx 0.043\\% \\) chance per event\n\n### **Limitations of the Estimate**\n\n1. **Hypothetical Numbers:** The average number of public events is assumed and may not reflect actual figures.\n2. **Variability Over Time:** Early presidents made fewer public appearances due to travel limitations, while modern presidents may attend more events.\n3. **Non-Randomness of Events:** Assassination attempts are influenced by specific motives and circumstances, not by chance alone.\n4. **Security Enhancements:** After each incident, security measures improved, reducing the likelihood of future attempts.\n\n### **Considerations for Actuarial Analysis**\n\nActuarial statistics rely on large datasets of similar, repeatable events to calculate probabilities. Presidential assassinations are rare and influenced by unique factors, making actuarial methods less applicable. Additionally, the emotional and societal impact of such events extends beyond what can be captured by statistical probabilities.\n\n### **Conclusion**\n\nWhile it&#x27;s possible to estimate a rough probability of an assassination occurring during a presidential parade or public event, the resulting percentage is extremely low and subject to significant uncertainty. The rarity of these events, coupled with their dependence on specific historical and social contexts, limits the usefulness of such calculations.\n\n### **Recommendations**\n\n- **Historical Research:** For a more precise analysis, detailed historical records of presidential schedules and public events would be necessary.\n- **Contextual Analysis:** Understanding the sociopolitical factors surrounding each assassination attempt provides more insight than statistical probabilities.\n- **Security Studies:** Evaluations by security experts offer practical assessments of risk and inform protective measures more effectively than actuarial statistics in this context.\n\n### **Final Thoughts**\n\nAssessing the likelihood of a presidential assassination using actuarial statistics is challenging due to the unique and infrequent nature of these events. While historical data can offer some perspective, the complexities involved mean that such probabilities should be interpreted with caution and an understanding of their limitations."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

A total of six manned missions landed on the lunar surface:\n\n1. **Apollo 11 (July 20, 1969):** Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to walk on the Moon, while Michael Collins orbited above.\n2. **Apollo 12 (November 19, 1969):** Charles Conrad and Alan Bean landed on the Moon; Richard Gordon remained in lunar orbit.\n3. **Apollo 14 (February 5, 1971):** Alan Shepard and Edgar Mitchell landed; Stuart Roosa stayed in orbit.\n4. **Apollo 15 (July 30, 1971):** David Scott and James Irwin landed; Alfred Worden orbited the Moon.\n5. **Apollo 16 (April 21, 1972):** John Young and Charles Duke landed; Thomas Mattingly orbited.\n6. **Apollo 17 (December 11, 1972):** Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt landed; Ronald Evans orbited.\n\n**Evidence Supporting the Moon Landings:**\n\n- **Lunar Samples:** Astronauts brought back 382 kilograms (842 pounds) of Moon rocks and soil, which have been studied worldwide and are unlike Earth materials.\n- **Photographic and Video Evidence:** Thousands of photos and hours of video footage document the missions.\n- **Equipment Left on the Moon:** Instruments like the Lunar Laser Ranging Retroreflector arrays are still operational. Scientists use them to measure the distance between the Earth and the Moon with high precision.\n- **Global Tracking:** Observatories and tracking stations around the world monitored the missions, including those in countries not aligned with the U.S., such as the Soviet Union.\n- **Third-Party Verification:** Independent organizations and countries have confirmed the landings. For example, the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter has photographed the landing sites, showing equipment and footprints left by astronauts.\n\n**Is There Really a Dark Side to the Moon?**\n\nThe term &quot;dark side of the Moon&quot; is a common misconception. Here&#x27;s the accurate explanation:\n\n- **Tidally Locked Rotation:** The Moon is tidally locked with Earth, meaning it rotates on its axis in the same amount of time it takes to orbit Earth\u2014about 27.3 days. This synchronization causes the same side (the &quot;near side&quot;) to always face Earth.\n  \n- **Far Side vs. Dark Side:**\n  - **Far Side:** The side of the Moon that is not visible from Earth is called the &quot;far side.&quot;\n  - **Dark Side Misnomer:** The far side is not perpetually dark. It experiences day and night cycles just like the near side. Each side of the Moon gets roughly two weeks of sunlight followed by two weeks of darkness.\n\n- **Exploration of the Far Side:**\n  - **First Images:** The Soviet Luna 3 spacecraft photographed the far side in 1959.\n  - **Recent Missions:** In 2019, China&#x27;s Chang&#x27;e 4 mission successfully landed a rover on the Moon&#x27;s far side, the first ever to do so.\n\n**Summary:**\n\n- The U.S. moon landings are well-documented historical events supported by substantial evidence.\n- The &quot;dark side of the Moon&quot; is a misnomer; both sides receive sunlight. The far side is simply the side we cannot see from Earth due to the Moon&#x27;s synchronous rotation.\n\n**Feel free to ask if you have more questions about the Moon, space exploration, or related topics!**"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
